questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with adenopathy of the medial group of superficial inguinal lymph nodes on the right side. Which of the following is the primary site resulting in this finding?

choices.text: Skin of the right lower limb

questions.solution:
Upper Lateral Group

  • Skin & fascia from the upper lateral part of the thigh
  • Gluteal region
  • Back below the umbilicus

Upper medial Group

  • The anterior abdominal wall below the umbilicus
  • Perineum including external genitalia EXCEPT for Glans penis/clitoris.
  • The anal canal below the pectinate line
  • Vagina below the hymen.
  • Penile part of male urethra
  • Supero lateral angle of uterus via round ligament.

Vertical Group

  • Skin & fascia of lower limb ( Great Saphenous territory).
  • The short saphenous territory.

Deep Inguinal Lymph Nodes

  • Superficial inguinal lymph nodes
  • Popliteal nodes
  • Glans penis / Glans Clitoris

questions.text: A 60-year-old businessman is evaluated by his physician, who determines that his blood pressure is significantly elevated at 185/130 mm Hg. Laboratory tests reveal an increase in plasma renin activity, plasma aldosterone level, and left renal vein renin level. His right renal vein renin level is decreased. What is the most likely cause of the patient’s hypertension-

choices.text: Adrenal adenoma secreting aldosterone and cortisol

questions.solution: In this patient, hypertension is most likely caused by left renal artery stenosis, which led to increased renin secretion by the left kidney. The increased plasma renin activity causes an increased secretion of aldosterone, which increases Na+ reabsorption by the renal distal tubule. The increased Na+ reabsorption leads to increased blood volume and blood pressure. The right kidney responds to the increase in blood pressure by decreasing its renin secretion. Right renal artery stenosis causes a similar pattern of results, except that renin secretion from the right kidney, not the left kidney, is increased. Aldosterone-secreting tumors cause increased levels of aldosterone but decreased plasma renin activity (as a result of decreased renin secretion by both kidneys).

questions.text: A 65-year-old solo traveler loses all her bag of supplies. She has been wandering without food and water for the last 12 hours. Her urine osmolarity is measured to be 970mOsm/L. Where is the maximum water reabsorption occurring in this lady?
questions.solution: She is dehydrated -so there is increased secretion of ADH leading to increased water reabsorption in DCT and CD. Her urine osmolarity is increased indicating that kidneys are functioning normally. Regardless of the person’s hydration status – maximum water is reabsorbed always in PCT (60-70%).

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to your office complaining of occasional headaches. On exam, you note several pigmented spots on his trunk. You also discover a few rubbery cutaneous tumors on his neck. The cells composing these skin tumors most likely originated from which of the following structures?
questions.solution: This patient has clinical features of neurofibromatosis type I (von Recklinghausen disease), an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder caused by mutations in the NF1 tumor suppressor gene. Patients typically develop hyperpigmented macules (cafe-au-lait spots) over the trunk soon after birth and are at increased risk of developing central nervous system neoplasms which can cause elevated intracranial pressure and headache. Patients characteristically develop numerous cutaneous neurofibromas comprised mostly of Schwann cells, which are embryologically derived from the neural crest.

questions.text: A 10-yr old boy was admitted for surgery of cleft lip. Suddenly he had acute pain in abdomen. On examination, he had Xanthomas. On investigation, we found milky plasma. Which lipoprotein is increased:
questions.solution:
Milky plasma means Chylomicrons are increased.

Chylomicrons contains TGs. But TG is a lipid and chylomicron is a lipoprotein (question is asking lipoprotein). This is a picture of Type I Hyperlipoproteinemia, which is due to the defect in Lipoprotein Lipase enzyme.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man suffering from carcinoma of the prostate showed areas of sclerosis and collapse of T10 and T11 vertebrae in X-ray. The spread of this cancer to the above vertebrae was must probably through:
questions.solution: Prostatic venous plexus communicates with the Internal vertebral plexus of veins and is a possible route for the spread of carcinoma.

questions.text: Gentle neck massage just below the angle of the right mandible in a patient who presents with sudden onset of palpitations produces an immediate improvement in his condition. This maneuver improved his condition by

choices.text: Increasing the sympathetic outflow to the SA node
Prolonging the ventricular myocardium refractory period

questions.solution: This is a patient of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia. Massage over the neck causes a decrease in sympathetic outflow to the heart and an increase in parasympathetic cardiac tone. This in turn causes a prolongation of the AV conduction time. This is especially helpful in PSVT because it abolishes the re-entrant circuit.

questions.text: Which of the following does not favor formation of euchromatin due to changes occurring at cytosine residues at CpG islands in DNA?
questions.solution:
The CpG sites or CG sites are regions of DNA where a cytosine nucleotide is followed by a guanine nucleotide in the linear sequence of bases along its 5’ → 3’ direction. CpG is shorthand for 5’-C-phosphate-G-3’.

CpG islands (or CG islands) are regions with a high frequency of CpG sites.

Methylation of CpG sites in the promoter of a gene may inhibit gene expression by not allowing the conversion of heterochromatin to euchromatin.

There is also evidence that low folate status results in impaired methylation of CpG islands in DNA, which is a factor in the development of colorectal and other cancers.

questions.text: A 2-day-old infant is diagnosed with transposition of the great arteries. If this condition were to be left untreated, it would be fatal. Which of the following structures must remain patent so that the infant can survive until surgical correction of the malformation?
questions.solution: In a case of transposition of the great arteries, oxygenated blood travels from the left ventricle into the pulmonary trunk, where it will eventually reach the lungs. In contrast, the aorta would be carrying deoxygenated blood into the systemic circulation. A patent ductus arteriosus acts as a shunt between the aorta and pulmonary trunk, allowing oxygenated and deoxygenated blood to mix and therefore allowing some oxygenated blood to reach the tissues.

questions.text: A patient recovering from a traumatic injury to the face now finds himself unable to chew his food. On physical examination, his jaw deviates to the right side. The nerve that has been injured in this patient exits the skull through which of the following foramina?
questions.solution:
All the given features indicate that the Mandibular nerve is involved hence Foramen ovale is correct.

MALE structures pass through foramen ovale

M→ Mandibular nerve

A → Accessory meningeal artery

L → Lesser petrosal nerve

E → Emissary vein

[occasionally, Anterior trunk of Middle meningeal vein passes through it]

  • The Middle meningeal artery passes through the Foramen spinosum

questions.text: Which of the following mucopolysaccharide does not contain acidic sugar?

A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room with abdominal pain, mental status changes, and fatigue. On history, the physician finds that the patient lives in an older house and has been sucking on the paint chips containing lead making the doctor suspicious of lead poisoning. Lead typically interferes with which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Lead inhibits hemoglobin synthesis by inhibiting d-ALA dehydratase.

Cytochrome oxidase is a component of complex IV of the electron transport chain, which is inhibited by cyanide and carbon monoxide, but not by lead.

UMP synthase is defective in the genetic condition of hereditary orotic aciduria. UMP synthase is not sensitive to the presence of lead.

Patients with acute intermittent porphyria have a deficiency of porphobilinogen deaminase. Lead does not affect this enzyme.

questions.text: A 7-month-old male infant is admitted to the emergency room with vomiting, lethargy, and irritability. Diagnostic tests reveal plasma ammonium levels of 200 μM. The mother reveals that one of her sons died in infancy after a similar episode, although she has never had such an episode. Based on the high ammonium levels and the family history, the physician suspects that the patient has a deficiency in ornithine transcarbamoylase (OTC), an X-linked disorder. To test this diagnosis, the physician orders additional tests on levels of particular metabolites in the blood plasma and urine. Which of the results below support the diagnosis of OTC deficiency?

choices.text: Low levels of glutamine and alanine

questions.solution:
• Increase in Bloodglutamine indicates hyperammonemia, which occurs in all enzyme defect of urea cycle
  • Increased uracil indicateOrnithine trans carbamoylase deficiency
  • Orotic acid, OMP, UMP are increased in OTC defect.

OTC deficiency (Excess carbamoyl phosphatefrommitochondriaenterscytoplasmand takes part inpyrimidine synthesis)

  • If citrulline is increased then it is Argino succinate synthetase deficiency. ( OPTION II)

questions.text: A 3 month old boy presents with poor feeding and growth, low muscle tone (hypotonia), the elevation of blood lactic acid, and mild acidosis(blood ph 7.3-7.35) the ratio of pyruvate to lactate in serum is elevated and there is decreased conversion of pyruvate to acetyl coenzyme A in fibroblasts? Which of the following compounds should be considered for therapy?
questions.solution:
• Congenital Lactic Acidosis may occur due to deficiency of thiamine (B1) which is required for Pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) which converts pyruvate to Acetyl CoA.
  • PDH requires 5 coenzymes: Lipoic acid and four B-complex Vitamins – Thiamine -B1; Riboflavin-B2 or FAD; Niacin-B3 or NAD; Pantothenic acid-B5).
  • In case of Thiamine deficiency, this reaction will be affected and pyruvate will accumulate leading to the formation of lactate and finally leading to Lactic Acidosis (see fig).

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is used for the detection of variations in DNA sequence and Gene expression?
questions.solution:
Microarraycandetect variations in DNA sequences, andenables description of gene expression.

Microarray/ChIP/Bioarray /GeneArray

  • Probes are immobilized on a solid support
  • DNA, RNA or protein can be detected.
  • Powerful tool for screening global pattern of gene expression.

⇒Detects:

  • Mutiple mutations
  • Mutiple gene expression analysis
  • Global pattern of gene expression
  • SNPs and copy number variations
  • Genetic transfer of disease
  • Protein-DNA interactions
  • Methylation patterns (epigenetic status)
  • Histone modifications
  • Can'tdetectAneuploidy

⇒Applications:

  • Genotyping
  • Genetic testing
  • Forensic analysis
  • Cancer mutations
  • Genetic linkage analysis

questions.text: An increase in stroke volume and heart rate is observed in a 25-year-old man when he runs for six miles on a treadmill. His VO2 maximum is 30% during the exercise. Which of the following will you expect to decrease at the peak of his exertion?
questions.solution: Increased heart rate and cardiac output with preservation of PaO2 and PaCO2 are consistent with integrated CVS response to exercise. Heart rate and cardiac output increases to meet increased tissue oxygen demands and respiratory rate increases to eliminate excess CO2 produced. In mild to moderate-intensity exercise – O2 uptake increases from 250mL to 4Ls/min and CO2 production increases from 200mL to 8L/min. So, this compensates for the fall in PaO2 and rise in PaCO2. Arterial PO2, PCO2, and pH remain essentially normal in most levels of exercise. With increased severity of exercise, due to more O2 extraction from the arterial blood- venous PO2 decreases, and venous PCO2 increases.

questions.text: A newborn infant develops its first cold, and is fussy and cannot eat. After missing a few feedings, the child becomes quite lethargic, and the parents rush the child to the emergency department. Blood analysis indicates elevated levels of lactate and uric acid, and significantly decreased levels of glucose. After stabilizing the child with glucose infusions, a glucagon challenge is given to the infant, and blood glucose levels do not increase but decrease slightly. The accumulation of which metabolite in the liver is most responsible for the elevated uric acid seen in the circulation?
questions.solution:
The child has von Gierke disease, a lack of glucose-6-phosphatase activity.

The lack of glucose-6-phosphatase leads to glucose 6-phosphate accumulation under conditions of glucose export from the liver, and the excess glucose 6-phosphate has three potential fates:

1. synthesize more glycogen (due to allosteric activation of phosphorylated glycogen synthase),

2. produce lactate (glycolysis is forced to be active by high substrate concentrations, and gives rise to lactate formation),

3. Produce ribose 5-phosphate (through the oxidative reactions of the HMP shunt pathway).

As ribose 5-phosphate accumulates, PRPP synthetase will convert the ribose 5-phosphate to PRPP, which then initiates the denovo purine biosynthetic pathway, and the purines are overproduced.

With excess purines, they are then degraded to uric acid, which increases in concentration and leads to precipitation, and gout.

questions.text: A 77-year-old female patient is brought to the emergency department after her daughter noticed she has been having meaningless speech. When assessing the patient, she calls the chair a table, and at times would make up new words. Her speech is fluent, but with paraphasic errors. Her repetition is impaired. On physical examination, a right upper quadrant field-cut is appreciated, with impairment in comprehension and repetition. Which of the following structures is most likely involved in this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Arcuate fasciculus, inferior frontal gyrus, and superior temporal gyrus

questions.solution: This patient's clinical symptoms and physical exam findings are highly suggestive of Wernicke's aphasia, which involves the posterior 2/3rds of the superior temporal gyrus. Wernicke's aphasia is receptive aphasia; meaning, that speech is fluent, but comprehension is impaired. The differential for this language disorder is Wernicke’s and Transcortical sensory aphasia. The differentiating factor between these two is whether their repetition is intact. Based on the clinical vignette, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with Wernicke’s aphasia due to her impaired repetition. Lesions in the arcuate fasciculus describe a conduction aphasia. This type of aphasia is characterized by fluent speech, intact comprehension, and impaired repetition. Lesions in the inferior frontal gyrus of the frontal lobe describe a Broca's aphasia, which is expressive aphasia. Lesions in the arcuate fasciculus, inferior frontal gyrus, and superior temporal gyrus describe global aphasia.

questions.text: Scientists working for a national endocrinology institute are investigating the specifics underlying glucose transport across skeletal muscle cell membranes. In one of the experiments, they observe that the transport of D- glucose is much faster than L- glucose across the muscle cell membranes. Which of the following processes is involved in the transport of glucose across the skeletal muscle membrane?
questions.solution: Glucose transport across the skeletal muscle membrane is via GLUT-4 which is insulin-mediated. It is a type of facilitated diffusion transport and is specific for D- Glucose than L- glucose.

questions.text: Taimoor, a 5-year-old boy has had episodic periods during which areas of his skin would develop a rash, which would spontaneously resolve in a week to 10 days. His pediatrician told the boy’s parents to give him niacin the next time this occurred and a high-protein diet, and when they did, the rash resolved in a day or two. A likely disorder that this child has is which one of the following?
questions.solution:
Hartnup’s disease(also known as "pellagra-like dermatosis" or "Hartnup disorder") is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder affecting the absorption & reabsorption of nonpolar amino acids (particularly tryptophan). Tryptophan is used to synthesize serotonin, melatonin, and niacin. The deficiency of niacin leads to pellagra.

Cystinuria is a different transport defect, which affects dibasic amino acid transporter.

Ornithine translocase deficiency, also called hyperornithinemia-hyperammonemia-homocitrullinuria (HHH)syndrome, is a rare autosomal recessive, urea cycle transporter defect, which causes ammonia to accumulate in the blood.

Alkaptonuria is due to a defect in homogentisic acid oxidase.

questions.text: The mesentery of the small intestine, along with its attachment to the posterior abdominal wall, crosses all of the following structures except
questions.solution:
1. The root of mesentery lies on the right side of the abdominal cavity and crosses right gonadal vessels (not left).
  2. The root of the mesentery lies along a line running diagonally from the duodenojejunal flexure on the left side of the second lumbar vertebral body to the right sacroiliac joint.
  3. It crosses over the third (horizontal) part of the duodenum, aorta, inferior vena cava, right ureter, and right psoas major.
  4. It does not cross the left ureter, left gonadal vessels, or superior mesenteric artery.
  5. Superior mesenteric artery is a content of the mesentery.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with fissures in the mouth, tingling sensation, and peripheral neuropathy. Investigations showed reduced glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin deficiency is the likely cause of this?
questions.solution:
Vitamin B2, also known asWarburg Yellow enzyme.

  • Active form of this is FMN, FAD. It is involved in oxidation-reduction reactions.
  • In its deficiency, there isdecreased activity of glutathione reductase, as this enzyme is dependent on FAD.

B2Deficiency: Riboflavinosis--->characterized by:

  • Corneal vascularization (earliest sign of deficiency).
  • Glossitis – inflammation of the tongue (magenta tongue- characteristic)
  • Cheilosis – redness and shiny appearance of lips
  • Angular stomatitis (lesions at the mucocutaneous junction at corners of the mouth), leading to painful fissures
  • Seborrheic dermatitis – rough scaly skin because of desquamation

Option 1- Vitamin B1 – Thiamin Nutritional Status can Be assessed by Erythrocyte Transketolase Activity-Thiamin deficiency can result in three distinct syndromes: a chronic peripheral neuritis, beriberi and Wernicke encephalopathy with Korsakoff psychosis.

Option 3-Vitamin B6-The most widely used method of assessing vitamin B6 status is by measuring the activity of erythrocyte transaminases.

-The active form of vitamin B6 is the coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate (PLP).

- Pyridoxine deficiency is associated with neurological symptoms such as depression, irritability, nervousness and mental confusion.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man expresses his concern about developing colon cancer to his physician. He states that his father and grandmother died of colon cancer. After a normal physical examination, negative Hemoccult tests, and unremarkable colonoscopy, the physician recommends a diet low in fat and high in fiber. The doctor explains that studies have shown a decreased risk for colon cancer with insoluble fiber consumption. Which of the following glycosidic bonds prevents humans from completely digesting fiber?
questions.solution:
The glucose ß (1-4) glucose glycosidic bond, found in cellulose, a major component of fiber, cannot be digested by human enzymes.

Humans can, however, digest:

  1. glucose a (1-4) glucose (starch, glycogen, maltose) bonds,
  2. galactose b (1-4) glucose (lactose) bonds,
  3. glucose (a 1-2) fructose (sucrose) bonds, and
  4. glucose a (1-6) glucose (glycogen, isomaltose) bonds.

questions.text: A patient presents with yellowish eyes and skin. He also has itching, pain in the upper right side of the abdomen, and weight loss. Laboratory analysis of urine bilirubin indicates obstructive jaundice. The test of which of the following enzyme will substantiate these findings?
questions.solution:
Option A: ALP

  • ALP (Alkaline Phosphatase) catalyzes the removal of phosphate group from organic phosphate esters at alkaline pH.
  • There are 4 isoenzymes for the ALP enzyme:
    • ALP-I → Intestinal
    • ALP-L → Tissue non-specific, present mainly in the liver, bone, and kidneys
    • ALP-P → Placental Iso enzyme present, also called Regan isoenzyme, increased during pregnancy.
    • GC type (Germ cell type) → Present in Germ cell
  • Very high levels of the enzyme alkaline phosphatase are seen in obstructive jaundice and are considered one of the best enzyme biomarkers for biliary obstruction.
  • ALP is mainly produced in hepatocytes of the liver and osteoblasts of bones.
  • It is present in the canalicular membranes of hepatocytes. When the release of bile is obstructed, causing obstructive jaundice, it increases the translation of ALP mRNA. This causes an increase in ALP, which moves to sinusoids. This can be seen as a high level of ALP in laboratory testing.
  • Increased ALP levels are seen in:
    • The liver diseases mainly biliary obstruction, hepatitis, and cirrhosis.
    • Bone → Paget’s disease, osteoporosis, osteoblastic bone tumor, osteomalacia
    • Hyperthyroidism
  • Decreased ALP is seen in:
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Women taking OCPs and estrogen therapy.

Option B: AST

  • AST is remarkably increased in hepatitis and liver cirrhosis.

Option C: ALT

  • ALT is remarkably increased in Budd-Chiari syndrome and autoimmune diseases of the liver.

Option D: Aminotransferase

  • Aminotransferases increase remarkably as compared to ALP in diseases of hepatocellular origin such as hepatitis, autoimmune diseases of the liver, alcohol-related diseases of the liver, and liver cirrhosis.

questions.text: A 45 years old patient with end-stage renal disease underwent a renal transplant. The upper 1/3 of the ureter of the transplanted kidney is retained and attached to the recipient patient's bladder. Which of the following arteries is the major source of blood supply to the upper ureter?
questions.solution:
Exp:

  • The renal arteries supply blood to the upper ureter
  • common iliac arteries, branches from the abdominal aorta, and the gonadal arteries supply the middle portion of the ureter
  • branches of the internal iliac artery supply the most distal part of the ureter.

questions.text: A dental hygienist is concerned about the effects of radiation on the in utero development of her baby. During which of the following periods is theembryo most susceptible to environmental influences that could inducethe formation of nonlethal congenital malformations?

choices.text: Fertilization to 1 week of fetal life
The second week of fetal life
The third to eighth weeks of fetal life
The third month of fetal life

questions.solution:
• Exposure of theembryo to harmful environmental factors (teratogens),such as chemicals, viruses, and/or radiation,can occur at any time.
  • During thethird through eighth weeks of embryonic life,organ systems are developing and are mostsusceptible to teratogens.
  • During that time, each organ system has its own specific period of peak susceptibility. Exposure of the embryo toteratogens during the first 2 weeks of fetal life generally induces spontaneous abortion and is, therefore, lethal.
  • After the eighth week of intrauterinedevelopment,teratogenic exposuregenerally results in retardation of organ growth rather thanin new structural or functional changes.

questions.text: A 28 years old male presents to your office complaining of lower abdominal discomfort. Physical examination reveals right-sided testicular enlargement that feels like a 'bag of worms' when the patient stands up The venous blood from the affected testicle drains directly into the:
questions.solution: Exp: Right Gonadal and Suprarenal veins drain into IVC whereas left Gonadal and Suprarenal veinsdrain into the left renal vein.

questions.text: A 38-year-old homeless man who has not received any medical care in the last 20 years presents with 2 days of shortness of breath, chills, fever, drooling, painful swallowing, and a “croupy” cough. A physical examination reveals bluish discoloration of his skin and a tough, gray membrane adhered to his pharynx. The underlying mechanism through which this disease affects normal cells in which one of the following?

choices.text: DNA synthesis is inhibited in the target cells.
RNA synthesis is inhibited in the target cells.
The process of protein synthesis is inhibited in the target cells.
The plasma membrane becomes leaky in the target cells.

questions.solution:
The man has contracted diphtheria, and needs the diphtheria antitoxin and then antibiotics to remove the offending organism, C. diphtheriae.

As the patient has not received medical care over the past 20 years, he has also missed his diphtheria vaccine, which should be received every 10 years.

Diphtheria toxin blocks eukaryotic protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylation of an amino acid residue of initiation factor (eEF-2), which inhibits this protein activity and cause inhibition of ribosome translocation in the cells ultimately resulting in stopping of protein synthesis..

Translocation

  • Movement of the ribosome on mRNA (Ribosome moves from 5' end towards the 3' end of mRNA during protein synthesis).
  • Requires 1 GTP and Elongation factor (EF-G).

questions.text: Research is being done at National Nephrology Institute to study the mechanism of urine dilution and concentration in humans. Using a special procedure- tubular fluid osmolarity is measured from different parts of the nephron. 1100 mOsm/L tubular fluid sample is withdrawn after 12 hrs of water deprivation in the animal. Which is the site most likely sampled assuming that the physiology of this animal mirrors human physiology?
questions.solution: Dehydration stimulates ADH secretion – it acts on the collecting ducts increasing their permeability to water. Thus, in the presence of vasopressin the collecting duct contains the most concentrated urine and TAL of LOH and early DCT contains the most dilute urine.

questions.text: A 59-year-old male presents to the emergency room complaining of substernal chest pain. He reports a three-hour history of dull substernal chest pain that radiates into his left arm and jaw. He has experienced similar chest pain before that was brought on with exertion, but this pain is more severe and occurred with rest. His past medical history includes gout, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. An EKG demonstrates ST segment depression. Serum troponin is elevated. In addition to aspirin, oxygen, and morphine, he is started on a sublingual medication. What is the main physiologic effect of this medication?
questions.solution: The most likely diagnosis in this patient is a non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). Nitroglycerin is a sublingually administered venodilator that is used to decrease cardiac preload, thereby decreasing cardiac oxygen demand. Nitrates, often in the form of nitroglycerin or nitroprusside, are administered sublingually and act as potent venodilators. Venous dilation causes pooling of blood in the venous vasculature thereby decreasing cardiac preload and reducing myocardial oxygen demand. Of note, although the main physiologic effect of nitrates is to venodilate and therefore decrease preload, they also have a secondary effect of decreasing afterload by promoting post-aortic muscular relaxation and decreasing arterial wall stress. Increasing preload would increase myocardial oxygen demand, thus worseningangina pain. Decreasing afterload is another way to decrease myocardial oxygen demand. Nitrates do decrease afterload by promoting arterial vasodilation; however, their main physiologic effect is to decrease preload via venodilation. Increasing contractility would increase myocardial oxygen demand. Inotropes such as dobutamine and digoxin are used to increase contractility in patients with heart failure.

questions.text: In an experimental model, a compound is centrally administered to rats. Following administration, the rats display increased desire for food and increased appetite. The administered compound is most likely similar to which of the following
questions.solution: Neuropeptide-Y (NPY) is a peptide hormone that increases hunger. Many peptide hormones are produced in the gastrointestinal tract. In addition to their roles in the digestive process, some of these hormones influence eating behaviors. NPY acts centrally to increase hunger and also acts to decrease energy expenditure. Ghrelin is another peptide hormone which acts to increase hunger. Several hormones, including peptide YY, glucagon-like peptide 1, and cholecystokinin act to signal satiety.

questions.text: A research scientist attempts to understand the influence of carbon dioxide content in blood on its oxygen binding. The scientist adds carbon dioxide to the rabbit’s blood and measures the uptake of oxygen in the blood versus oxygen pressure in the peripheral tissue. He notes in one rabbit that with the addition of carbon dioxide with a pressure of 80 mmHg, the oxygen pressure in the peripheral tissue rose from 23 to 35 mmHg. How can this phenomenon be explained?
questions.solution: This question describes an experiment whereby high partial pressure of CO2 in tissues facilitated O2 unloading in peripheral tissues. This effect is known as the Bohr effect. Oxygen and carbon dioxide uptake in the blood is interrelated.

questions.text: A one-week-old infant presented with relentless vomiting, watery green diarrhea, abdominal distension, and failure to thrive. Further examination showed hepatosplenomegaly and increased cholesterol esters and triglyceride levels in plasma. X-ray showed calcification of adrenals. The child most probably has a defect in which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Option D: Acid lipase

  • The calcification of adrenals is highly diagnostic of Wolman Disease.
  • It is a congenital autosomal recessive disease.
  • It is a cholesterol ester storage disease and occurs due to lysosomal acid lipase deficiency.
  • As a result of lipase deficiency, excess triglycerides will not be degraded and accumulates in cells.
  • Other clinical features include:
    • Vomiting
    • Watery green diarrhoea
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Poor weight gain
    • Decreased muscle tone
    • Developmental delay
  • Symptoms commonly begin early in infancy and childhood
  • There is no cure for Wolman’s disease. Treatment is by enzyme replacement therapy.
  • The picture below demonstrates bilateral adrenal calcification in an X-ray of a child with Wolman's disorder.

Option A: Acid maltase

  • The deficiency of acid maltase causes Pompe's disease (a glycogen storage disease) with features such as hypotonia, cardiomegaly in muscles, hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia in the liver.

Option B: Acid phosphatase

  • Acid phosphatase deficiency causes a rare autosomal recessive disorder that is characterised by hypotonia, lethargy, intermittent vomiting and opisthotonos.
  • It is associated with fatal outcomes in infancy.

Option C: Alkaline phosphatase

  • Alkaline phosphate deficiency in blood indicates Wilson's disease, which may be a result of celiac disease or malnutrition.

questions.text: A patient recovering from a traumatic injury to the face now finds himself unable to chew his food. On physical examination, his jaw deviates to the right side. The nerve that has been injured in this patient exits the skull through which of the following foramina?
questions.solution:
All the given features indicate that the Mandibular nerve is involved hence Foramen ovale is correct.

MALE structures pass through foramen ovale

M→ Mandibular nerve

A → Accessory meningeal artery

L → Lesser petrosal nerve

E → Emissary vein

[occasionally, Anterior trunk of Middle meningeal vein passes through it]

  • The Middle meningeal artery passes through the Foramen spinosum

questions.text: A 10 years old boy is brought to the emergency department because he is no longer able to fully extend the fingers of his right hand. he had suffered a right fibula fracture in a road accident 2 weeks before and was given a pair of crutches to use while his leg recovered. He lost that set of crutches and therefore he has been using his taller friend's crutches. which has been putting a lot of pressure on his axilla. On physical exam, he is found to have a wrist drop and decreased sensation over his posterior forearm and dorsal hand. Injury to which of the following nerves is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms –
questions.solution: Radial nerve is compressed in Axilla due to pressure by longer crutches and patient has developed wrist drop.

questions.text: A man presents to the ER after ingesting an insecticide. His respiration rate is very low. Information from the Poison Control Center indicates that this particular insecticide binds to and completely inhibits cytochrome C. Therefore, which one of the following would occur in this man’s mitochondria?

choices.text: Coenzyme Q would be in the oxidized state
Cytochromes a and a3 would be in the reduced state
The rate of ATP synthesis would be approximately zero
The rate of CO2 production would be increased

questions.solution:
If cytochrome C cannot function, all the components of the electron transport chain between it and O2 remain oxidized, and the components of the chain before cytochrome C are are in reduced form (See fig).

The electron transport chain will not function; O2 will not be consumed; a proton gradient will not be generated, and ATP will not be produced.

NADH will not be oxidized, thereby increasing the NADH/NAD+ ratio. Owing to this increased ratio, the TCA cycle will slow down and, therefore, CO2 production will decrease.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man complains of dryness of the mouth. On examination, he lacks salivary secretion from the submandibular gland. This indicates a lesion of which of the following nervous structures?

choices.text: Chorda tympani in the middle ear cavity

questions.solution:
Because Chorda tympani carries the salivatory fibers to the Submandibular gland

  • Chorda tympani nervecontainspreganglionic parasympathetic fibersresponsible forthe secretion of the submandibular gland.
  • The lingual nerve at its origin is not yet joined by the chorda tympani.
  • Superior cervical ganglion provides sympathetic fibers, which supply blood vessels in the submandibular gland.
  • A lesser petrosal nerve contains preganglionic parasympathetic fibers that synapse in the otic ganglion.
  • The auriculotemporal nerve contains postganglionic parasympathetic fibers, which are responsible for the secretion of the parotid gland.

questions.text: A benign tumor in the orbit of a 49-year-old man compresses a structure that runs through both the superior orbital fissure and the common tendinous ring. Which of the following structures is most likely damaged?
questions.solution: Abducens nerve passes through both the superior orbital fissure and the common tendinous ring.

questions.text: The diagram below illustrates single isometric twitch contractions of two skeletal muscles, A and B, in response to a depolarizing stimulus. Which of the following best describes the muscle A?

choices.text: Adapted for slow and sustained contraction

questions.solution:
Muscle A is a Fast muscle fiber adapted for phasic contractions- these have large muscle fibers, faster conduction velocity, dependent upon anaerobic metabolism, and are innervated by large muscle fibers.

  • Muscle B ischaracteristic of aslow-twitch muscle(type 1) composed of predominantlyslow-twitch muscle fibers. Thesefibers are smaller in sizeand areinnervatedbysmaller nerve fibers.
  • They typically have a moreextensive blood supply,agreater number ofmitochondria, andlarge amounts of myoglobin, all of whichsupport high levels of oxidative phosphorylation

questions.text: The physical examination involved in regenerative medicine research conduct a series of animal experiments to determine pulmonary tissue regeneration capacity. During one experiment, a Histologic examination of the massively injured tissues later shows a partial recovery of the alveolar epithelial lining. This regenerated tissue is most likely derived from which of the following cell types?
questions.solution:
Type II pneumocytes secrete surfactant and also help in the regeneration of tissue.

  • Type 1Pneumocytehelps ingaseous exchange.
  • Type 2Pneumocyteshelp in the production ofsurfactant.

questions.text: A34-year-old woman who has been taking oral contraceptives for many years presents with acute abdominal pain and fullness. Paracentesis harvests 200 mL of bloody fluid. Imaging studies show a 6-cm mass in the liver that is subsequently resected. Histological examination of this specimen would most likely reveal this to be which of the following?
questions.solution:
Liver cell adenomasmay occur after several years of taking oral contraceptives but the actualmechanism of tumor formation is unknown.

The clinical presentation is often acute abdominal pain due to necrosis of the tumor and hemorrhage. Given the patient’s history, liver cell adenoma is by far the most likely choice. Cholangiocarcinomas are rare tumors that arise in the intrahepatic bile ducts, there is an association with the liver fluke, Clonorchis sinensis.

Focal nodular hyperplasia is a tumor-like lesion that occurs more frequently in women. It has a weak association with oral contraceptive use. On cut section, ittypically has a central stellate scar. It is usually asymptomatic and is only resected in the symptomatic patient

questions.text: A patient admitted in the ICU Consuming some poison. He had features of broncho-dilatation, increase in temperature, constipation and tachycardia. The poison consumed is
questions.solution:
• Acommon mnemonic used to describe the physiologic manifestationsof atropine overdose is: "hot as a hare, blind as a bat, dry as a bone, red as a beet, and mad as a hatter"
  • These associationsreflect the specific changes of warm, dry skin from decreasedsweating, blurry vision, decreased sweating/lacrimation, vasodilation, and central nervous system effects on muscarinic receptors, type 4 and 5.
  • This set of symptoms is known as anticholinergic toxidrome, and may also be caused by other drugs with anticholinergic effects, such asdiphenhydramine, phenothiazine antipsychotics and benztropine.

questions.text: In a study two groups of newborns are checked for their weights based on whether mothers received food supplements or not. The appropriate test which can be used for comparing the data is
questions.solution:
• Parametric test: assumes normality of a data. Data should be symmetrical. Not used for skewed data
  1. Student T test
  2. Paired T test
  3. ANOVA test
  • Non-parametrical test: Normality is not necessary. used for skewed data. Used in presence of any outlier.
  1. Mann-whittney test
  2. Wilcoxen signed rank test
  3. Kruskal wallis test

questions.text: Mr. Rushil has severe hypertension and is to receive minoxidil. Minoxidil is a powerful arteriolar vasodilator that does not act on autonomic receptor. When used in severe hypertension its effects would probably include

choices.text: Decreased mean arterial pressure and decreased cardiac contractility
Decreased mean arterial pressure and increased salt and water excretion by the kidney

questions.solution: Minoxidil is a powerful vasodilator and leads to Reflex stimulation of sympathetic system. Thus, it causes tachycardia, increased contractility and retention of and water by the kidney.

questions.text: A 40 year old male from bihar developed muscular rigidity, weakness and difficulty in walking. Subsequently he developed paralysis of lower limbs. His vitals are normal. On examination his ankle jerk and knee jerk are exaggerated. He gave history of khesari dal consumption. Which of the following toxin is responsible for this disease?
questions.solution:
This is case of lathyrism

Caused due to khesari dal consumption

Disease Toxin Adulterant
Lathyrism BOAA Khesari dal (Lathyrus sativus)
Epidemic dropsy Sanguinarine Argemome Mexicana (oil) added to mustard oil
Endemic ascites Pyrrolizidine (hepatotxic) Crotalaria seeds (Jhunjhunia)
Aflatoxicosis Aflatoxin Aspergillus flavus/ parasiticus
Ergotism Clavinet Claviceps fusiformis

questions.text: A 45 year old chronic alcoholic male is brought to emergency department with an alleged history of assaulting his neighbours.On examination he is found to have irrelevant talk.He hadf not consumed alcohol since last 4 days.He is diagnosed as delirium tremens.In this condition the person is-

choices.text: Not responsible for his act under section 84 IPC
Has Diminished responsibility for his act

questions.solution:
McNaughten’s Rule – Sec 84 IPC - Act of a person of unsound mind “Nothing is an offence which is done by a person ,who at the time of doingit,by reason of unsoundness of mind,is incapable of knowing the nature of the act or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law”

  • Sec 85 IPC - Act of a person incapable of judgment by reason of intoxication caused against his will.
  • Sec 86 IPC - Offence requiring a particular intent or knowledge committed by one who is intoxicated.

A person who is intoxicated and commits a crime the criminal responsibility will lie on the fact whether he has consumed the intoxicant with the intention of committing the crime or not.

A person suffering from Delirium tremens is free from criminal responsibility. Diminished responsibility– term used for borderline mental states – bordering upon but not amounting to insanity. Eg certain organic depressions, obsessional states and some paranoid states.

questions.text: A 42-years-old man develops acute renal failure. Laboratory studies also reveal hypocalcemia. What is the most likely mechanism underlying this electrolyte disturbance?
questions.solution: Hyperphosphatemia associated with renal failure is the likely cause for this patient’s hypocalcemic state. Phosphate excretion is impaired, and metabolic phosphate production is often increased. High serum levels of phosphate can lead to the deposition of calcium phosphate in tissues, decreasing the plasma calcium concentration.

questions.text: A Mexican immigrant presents with a 3-month history of weight loss, night sweats, a productive cough with blood-tinged sputum, anorexia, general malaise, and a low grade fever. A PPD skin test shows > 10 mm of induration. If the area of induration were biopsied, which of the following type of reactive cells would be found?
questions.solution:
• The CD4+ population of T lymphocytes, specifically TH1 cells, are responsible for the delayed hypersensitivity reaction seen with a skin test in a previously sensitized patient.
  • The clinical pattern in the test question is classic for reactivation or adult-type tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is diagnosed with an inherited disorder of the complement system after having recurrent sinopulmonary infections.All of the following are associated except:
questions.solution:
Defects in the complement pathway predisposes individuals to recurrent infections with encapsulated organisms such as H.influenzae, Neisseria species, or S. pneumoniae.

  • Late complement deficiency are prone for recurrents Neisserial infections (meningococci & gonococci both)
  • C1esterase inhibitor deficiency: leads to Hereditary Angioneurotic edema

questions.text: A 29-year-old sexually active man presents with painful urination and penile discharge. He reports no joint symptoms, rash, or fever. Examination of the prostate, testes, and penis are normal, and there is a visible discharge that can be expressed from the urethra. Microscopic examination is not possible in this clinic. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Treat for C. Trachomatis with azithromycin
Treat for N. Gonorrhoeae infection with ceftriaxone
Treat for N. Gonorrhoeae infection with penicillin
Treat for C. Trachomatis and N. Gonorrhoeae with azithromycin and ceftriaxone

questions.solution:
• Empiric treatment should include coverage for both Chlamydial infection (with azithromycin) and N. gonorrhoeae infection (usually with ceftriaxone).
  • There are numerous alternatives for N. gonorrhoeae infection, such as oral cefixime,oral ciprofloxacin, or intramuscular (IM) ceftriaxone. However, resistance to penicillin is too common to allow the routine use of this drug.

questions.text: A 50-year-old has a history of frequent episodes of renal colic with high calcium renal stones. The most useful diuretic in the treatment of recurrent calcium stones is
questions.solution: Thiazides cause hypercalcemia by decreasing the renal excretion of Ca". These are useful in a patient having hypercalciuria. In such a patient, thiazides decrease the excretion of Ca" in the kidney and thus reduces the chances of stone formation. Thus, option D is correct.

questions.text: This drug has to be administered to a 65 years old patient Uttam Singh, with a GFR of 60 ml/min. (assuming normal GFR is 120 ml/min). Liver and biliary functions are normal in this patient. What should be the dose rate of drug X in this patient
questions.solution: In this question 80 percent of drug is eliminated by renal route and 20 percent by non-renal routes (10 percent by hepatic metabolism and 10 percent by biliary secretion). - This patient has 50 percent renal fiction (60 m1/min of GFR instead of 120 ml/min). Thus, the drug that can be eliminated in this person is 20 percent (Non-renal route) + 40 percent (Rena] route 50 percent of 80 percent) - =60 percent - Thus, the dose rate should be 60 percent of the original. i.e. 50 mg/hr. x 60 percent = 30 mg/hr.

questions.text: The following is the Hematoxylin and Eosin Stained section from the heart of patient after myocardial infarction. What can yousay about the age of the infarction :
questions.solution:
Time Gross features Light microscope
Reversible injury
0-1/2 hr None None
Irreversible injury
½-4hr None
4-12 hr Dark mottling (occasional ) Usually none; variable waviness of fibers at border
12-24 hr Dark mottling Early coagulation necrosis; pyknosis of nuclei; myocyte hypereosinophilia; marginal contraction band necrosis; early neutrophilic infiltrate
1-3 days Mottling with yellow-tan infract center Coagulation necrosis, with loss of nuclei and striations; brisk interstitial infiltrate of neutrophils
3-7 days Hyperemic border; central yellow-tan softening Beginning disintegration of dead myofibers, with dying neutrophills; early phagocytosis of dead cells by macrophages at infarct border
7-10 days Maximally yellow-tan and soft, with depressed red-tan margins Well-developed phagocytosis of dead cells; granulation tissue at margins
10-14 days Red-gray depressed infarct borders Well-established granulation tissue with new blood vessels and collagen deposition
2-8 wk Gray-white scar, progressive from border toward core of infract Increased collagen deposition, with decreased cellularity
>2mo Scarring complete Dense collagenous scar

questions.text: A pregnant lady was treated with multiple drugs for her epilepsy. She gave birth to a child with the following features. Which of the antiepileptics was probably responsible for this teratogenic effect?
questions.solution:
The figure shows fetal hydantoin syndrome

FETAL HYDANTOIN SYNDROME :

  • Caused byPhenytoin
  • Due to toxic areneoxide metabolite.
  • Impaired DNA synthesis due to folate deficiency

TYPICAL FEATURES :

  • Hypoplastic phalanges
  • Cleft palate
  • Cleft Lip
  • Microcephaly

questions.text: A drug 'X' primarily reduces the static component of urinary obstruction in benign hypertrophy of prostate and takes more than 3 months to exert its beneficial effect. Which of the following is 'X'?
questions.solution: 5-a-reductase inhibitors are used to reduce the static component of urinary obstruction in BHP. It is delayed acting and takes more than 3 months to exert its beneficial effect. • Selective a, blockers are used to relieve the dynamic obstruction in BHP. These provide rapid symptomatic relief. Thus, option A is correct.

questions.text: If a 11 month old child has received two doses of DPT & polio comes for further immunization after 5 months of the last dose what should be done?

choices.text: Repeat the 2nd dose and continue rest of the course
Give 3rd dose and continue the course

questions.solution: There is no need to restart the schedule; and since DPT & OPV can be given after 1 year also so 3rd dose is given.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man on steroid therapy suffering from systemic vasculitis.Biopsy specimen displayed fibrinoid necrosis of the media accompanied by a transmural acute inflammatory infiltrate. Significant negative clinical findings included a normal aortic arch,absence of giant cells in the artery biopsy, normal upper airway examination, and no history of tobacco use. Which of the following disorders best correlates with these findings?
questions.solution:
• Polyarteritis nodosa is a systemic vasculitis primarilyseen in young adult males. Fibrinoid necrosis and acute inflammation are seen microscopically in the acute phase.
  • Mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome (Kawasaki disease) is a childhood disorder with coronary vasculitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, and acute onset. Takayasu disease is characterized by fibrosis of the upper aorta.
  • Temporal or giant cell arteritisa granulomatous arterial inflammation seen in the elderly. The superficial temporal and intercranial arteries are preferentially involved.
  • Thromboangiitisobliterans is an occlusive disease of small arteries strongly related to cigarette smoking.

questions.text: A 65-yrs-old woman developed a fever and watery diarrhea while on ampicillin for a urinary tract infection. A colonoscopic examination reveals yellow-white plaques surrounded by hemorrhagic borders on the mucosal surface of the colon. Which of the following is the test of choice for this patient’s disease?

choices.text: Gram’s stain of the yellowish material

questions.solution:
• The association of this patient’s complaints withantibiotic useand theappearance of the lesionsargue against a parasitic cause of diarrhea.
  • The patient has antibiotic –associated pseudomembranous colitis.
  • Colonoscopy in this diseaseshows whitish or yellowish plaques surrounded by hemorrhagic borders. It is due to an overgrowth of clostridium difficile.
  • Ampicillin and clindamycinare the most common antibiotics associated with pseudomembranous colitis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old systems analyst presents for evaluation of a bee sting allergy. He describes an episode in which he was stung on the forearm by a bee and, within 5 minutes, experienced pruritus, urticaria, and mild wheezing. The effector cell in this type of hypersensitivity is
questions.solution:
• This patient isexperiencing the early phase of type I hypersensitivity, characterized by pruritus and watery dischargefrom the nose, bronchospasm, mucus secretion in the airways, and a wheal-and-flare response with pruritus in the skin.
  • The mechanismof hypersensitivity involves prior sensitization of a population of TH2 cells that produced cytokines, including interleukin-4. The interleukin-4 causes B cells to switch their heavy chain class fromIgM to IgE. The IgE molecules then attach to mast cells or basophils.
  • With antigen (allergen) challenge, themast cells degranulateand release mediators, including histamine, which produces the anaphylactic response.

questions.text: Over a span of years, an individual develops thickening of the fascia of one palm, which eventually causes a flexion contracture of the hand, most markedly involving the fourth and fifth fingers. The patient most probably has which of the following?
questions.solution: The patient has palmar fibromatosis, also known as Dupuytren contracture. This is a benign condition that may stabolize spontaneously or may require surgical excision. Incidence is highest in patients older than 40 who have chronic diseases (including diabetes and liver disease).

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl presented to the OPD with complaints of several days of fever and sore throat. She had tender cervical lymphadenopathy. The Gram stain of throat swab revealed Gram positive cocci chains and culture showed beta haemolysis on blood agar. ASO titres are increased markedly. The organism that is the most likely cause of her symptoms can also leads which of the following sequelae?
questions.solution:
This patient has exudative pharyngitis, most likely from Streptococcus pyogenes.

Points in favour of Acute Rheumatic Fever caused by Streptococcus pyogenes:

  • history of fever and sore throat
  • ASO titres are increased markedly.
  • Gram positive cocci in chains
  • Culture showed beta haemolysis on blood agar.

Streptococcus pyogenes causes:

  • Acute pharyngitis
  • Skin infections: cellulitis, impetigo, erysipelas, necrotizing fasciitis
  • Scarlet fever
  • Non suppurative complications: Acute rheumatic fever, Acute glomerulonephritis
Acute Rheumatic Fever Acute Glomerulonephritis

-H/O sore throat

- Immune response marked

- Complement levels are normal

- Life long prophylaxis of penicillin required

- ASO Titres → > 200 Todd units

- H/O pyodermic infection

- Mild to moderate immune response.

- Complement → ↓ses, then normal

- Spontaneous to come & spontaneous to go

-Anti DNAse B → > 300-350 units

Group A streptococcal infections can be associated with scarlet fever, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, rheumatic fever and toxic shock syndrome.

Epstein–Barr virus is the most common cause of infectious mononucleosis and can cause an exudative pharyngitis, but is less likely in a 9-year-old.

questions.text: There are 100 children in a village 90 received BCG, 80 got DPT-1 + OPV-1, 70 DPT-2+ OPV-2, 60 got DPT-3+OPV-3, and 55 got measles. What is the drop out rate
questions.solution:
Fully Immunized Child:

A child who received One dose of BCG, Three doses of DPT and OPV, One dose of measles before one year of age.

For calculation of drop out rate = Total number of children – Children who received Measles

Drop Out Rate = 100 – 55 = 45

Two things which you should be aware of for this calculation:

  1. Not to leave out the 10 children who have been totally left out in immunization (90- 55 = 35; this wrong)
  2. Assumption is made that those children immunized with measles have also been immunised with other vaccines also

questions.text: A 40 year-old man presented with weight loss and painless lymphadenopathy. A node biopsy showed proliferation of germinal centers in the cortex and medulla. The enlarged centers consisted of poorly differentiated lymphocytes. The likeliest diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• Infollicular (nodular) lymphoma, there is an increase in the number and size of lymph follicles. These usually consist of small, poorlydifferentiated lymphocytes.
  • Lymphomasof diffuse types show a monotonouspattern of cells throughout the involved nodes andinvading the perinodal tissue.
  • Well differentiated lymphocytic lymphomas consist of sheets of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes.
  • Poorly differentiatedlymphocytic lymphomas are made up of large, poorly differentiated lymphocytes.
  • Histiocytic lymphomas are formed by transformed lymphocytes (only about 1 percent of “histiocytic”lymphomas are truly of histiocytic origin).
  • Undifferentiated lymphomasconsist of large, lymphoblastic cells and scattered palehistiocytes with abundant cytoplasm containing phagocytized material.

questions.text: A 22 yr old patient had unprotected sex. He went to doctor for counselling. doctor suggested him that a primary test for HIV will be done and if it comes positive then another diagnostic test has to be done. The primary screening test should have high?
questions.solution: A screening test must have high sensitivity. This reduces the number of false negatives.

questions.text: A 34-year old rickshaw puller has been using heroin for the past ten years. One evening his family members found him unconscious. He was brought to the casualty. On examination he had tachycardia, shallow breathing, constricted pupils. His blood pressure was 100/70 mm of Hg. He had brisk bilateral deep tendon reflexes. The planter reflexes were flexor on both sides. Which of the following is the best treatment for him?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of acute heroin intoxication. Heroin is an opioid. The drug of choice for any opioid overdose is Naloxone. Buprenorphine and Methadone are used for deaddiction and rehabilitation of opioid addicts but not for acute poisoning. Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine antagonist.

Treatment of opioids (opium, heroin, morphine etc..)

1)     Acute poisoning treatment: The drug of choice is naloxone – an opioid antagonist. It reduces the action of heroin. reverses all signs of opioid intoxication.

2)    Opioid addiction, dependence and withdrawal treatment: Both Buprenorphine and Methadone are used for Opioid addiction, dependence and withdrawal treatment. Buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist and Methadone is an opioid agonist

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman from a dry state who ingested rye for long time presented with complaints of weakness in both the lower limbs, nausea and fatigue. Over due course of time, she is completely unable to walk, What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
NEUROLATHYRISM

  • It is a crippling disease of the nervous system characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of the lower limb. mostly occur in adults.
  • TOXIN: BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine)
  • Adulterant: Khesari dal (Lathyrus Sativus)

questions.text: A addict develops delusion, misleading hallucination of sight and hearing and the feeling of creeping things of 'grains of sand' in the skin, he is addicted to:-
questions.solution:
Insects (bugs) crawling under the skin or presence of sand grain under the skin is a characteristic feature of chronic cocaine poisoning.

Chronic Cocaine Poisoning (COCAINISM/ COCAINOPHAGIA/COCAINOMANIA):

  • Unstable mental condition ,such as:
    • Toxic delirium
    • Psychotic disorder characterised by paranoid delusions, visual and tactile hallucination.
    • Tactile hallucinations are characteristic:
      • Associated with excoriation of the skin.
      • This is also called cocaine bugs/ Formication/ Magnan symptom
  • Sexual and reproductive dysfunction: There is loss of libido. Impotence and gynaecomastia occurs in male cocaine abusers. Women have major derangements in menstrual cycle function including galactorrhoea, amenorrhoea and infertility.
  • Crack Babies: Cocaine abuse by pregnant women has been associated with an increased risk of congenital malformations in the foetus called crack babies.
  • Tongue and teeth becomes black

questions.text: A new antibody based rapid kit is invented by ICMR to detect COVID-19. out of 1000 PCR positive patient, 100 are negative on this rapid kit and out of 1000 PCR negative patient 200 are positive. Which of the following is not true?
questions.solution:
• SENSITIVITY = 900/900+100 = 0.9 OR 90%
  • SPECIFICITY= 800/800+200= 0.8 OR 80%
  • PPV= 900/900+200= 81%
  • NPV = 800/800+100= 88.9%
Disease (Positive PCR) Disease Free (Negative PCR)
TEST POSITIVE 900 (TP) 200 (FP)
TEST NEGATIVE 100 (FN) 800 (TN)

questions.text: Malaria eradication program based on use of insecticide aims to reduce lifespan of mosquito larval to less than
questions.solution:
Life Cycle of Female Mosquito: Overall life span:

8 to 34 days

  • Larval stage: 5 to 7 days
  • Egg stage: 1- 2 days
  • Transformation to Adult stage: 7- 10 days
  • Adult: 2 weeks

questions.text: A patient on nitroprusside therapy developed cyanide toxicity. Sodium nitrate was administered i.v. to combat this poisoning. Beneficial effect of sodium nitrite in this case is dependent on

choices.text: Conversion of hemoglobin to methemoglobin by sodium nitrate
Direct chelation of cyanide with sodium nitrite
Facilitation of cyanocobalamin formation by sodium nitrate

questions.solution: Cyanide has very high affinity for the enzymes of respiratory chain particularly cytochrome oxidase. Methemoglobin possesses even higher affinity for cyanides. It can free the enzymes due to competitive inhibition for cyanide. Nitrates act by reducing hemoglobin to methemoglobin, which removes cyanide from the enzymes. Thus, option A is correct.

questions.text: A 35-year-old labourer 3 years back presented with single indurated penile ulcer not treated. Later he presented with skin rash with neurological symptoms for which he got treated. Test to monitor response to treatment is
questions.solution:
VDRL becomes negative with successful treatment, hence is used as a prognostic test.

VDRL can be used for treatment monitoring as specific tests remains positive (reactive) after the treatment.

  • A fourfold decrease in titre following therapy suggests adequate therapy, whereas a fourfold increase in titre of reaginic antibodies following therapy suggests reinfection or relapse.
  • FTA-ABS: Treponema-specific test. First test to be positive: FTA-ABS.

VDRL Test is a Flocculation test [Veneral Disease Research Lab]:

Used for diagnosis of syphilis.

Principle:Patients suffering from syphilis produce antibodies that react with cardiolipin antigen in a slide flocculation test, which is read using a microscope.

  • Antigen used:Cardiolipin,which is a lipoidal extract frombeef heart.
  • Patient's serum is inactivatedby heating at 560C for 30 minutes to remove non specific inhibitors.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male, Ram Lal suffering from renal failure, underwent kidney transplant. He was prescribed a nucleotide derivative following the organ transplant. The nucleotide derivates of therapeutic importance in this organ transplant is:
questions.solution: Azathioprine is the purine antimetabolite drug that is used as immunosuppressant ,but not used as anticancer drug. It is a prodrug and is activated in WBC to 6 mercaptopurine (active form). It inhibits WBC differentiation and hence bone marrow suppression is the major side effect of this drug. Its dose should be reduced if allopurinol is used along with it . 5FU and cytarabine are also antimetabolite drugs but useful for cancer treatment and not as immunosuppressive drugs

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents at the physician’s office with symptoms of coryza, conjunctivitis, low-grade fever, and Koplik’s spots. Choose the currently used vaccine strain to prevent this clinical condition?
questions.solution:
• A highly effective, safe, attenuated live measles virus vaccine is available.
  • The original live vaccines used the Edmonston strain developed by multiple passage through the human kidney, amnion and chick embryo cultures.
  • The Schwartz and Moraten strains so developed were safe but effective only in children older than 15 months.
  • The recommended age for measles vaccination in the developing countries is 9 months, while in the advanced countries it remains 15 months.

questions.text: A thirty-year old man presented with nausea, fever and jaundice of 5 days duration. Thebiochemical tests revealed a bilirubin of 6.7 mg/dl (conjugated 5.0 mg/dl) with SGOT/SGPT(AST/ALT) of 1230/900 IU/ml. The serological tests showed the presence of HBsAg, IgM anti HBcand HBeAg. The most likely diagnosis is

choices.text: Chronic hepatitis B infection with high infectivity
Acute hepatitis B infection with high infectivity
Chronic hepatitis B infection with low infectivity
Acute hepatitis B infection with low infectivity

questions.solution:
Acute hepatitis B infection with high infectivity

HBsAg HBeAg Anti-HBS Anti-HBe Anti-HBC
IgM IgG
Late incubation period or early hepatitis + + - - - -
Acute hepatitis + + - - + -
Late/chronic HBV infection + ± - - - +
Simple carrier + - - - - +
Super carrier + + - - - +
Past infection - - + + - +
Immunity following vaccination - - + - - -
“When+, it indicates high infectivity while – indicates low infectivity”.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man develops fever, neck stiffness, and headache. On examination, his blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg, pulse 100/min, temperature 38.7°C, and neck flexion is very painful. CSF examination was done and Gram staining of the culture showed lanceolate shaped, Gram positive diplococci The ears, throat, and sinuses are normal; there are no focal neurologic signs, and the remaining examination is normal. There are no reported similar cases in the community. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
In the given CSF Gram stain, diplococcus arrangement is shown which is characteristic feature of pneumococcus or Streptococcus pneumoniae which causes conjunctivitis, otitis media, meningitis, pneumonia and sinusitis.

Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of meningitis in adults.

  1. Streptococcus pneumoniae is responsible for 10-20 percent of meningitis cases in children ages 1 month to 15 years.
  2. Neisseria meningitidis range from 25-40 percent.
  3. Group A and B Streptococci appear to be involved only 2-4 percent of the time.
  4. Under the conditions described above (CSF showing gram positive diplococcic), Streptococcus pneumoniae would be the most likely etiologic agent.

questions.text: A 65-years-old man complains of weakness, weight loss, and bone pain. He reports having progressive difficulty seeing. Physical examination is significant for hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy. Serum protein electrophoresis reveals and M-protein spike, with and elevated serum IgM level. Bone marrow aspiration shows intensely eosinophilic plasma cells. Urine contains Bence-jones proteins. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The challenge in answering this question arises from the difficulty in differentiating the very similar disease that cause monoclonal gammopathy. The key to answering correctly is making sure not to use only one piece of information as the sole distinguishing factor. You must look at the whole picture-clinical presentation, physical exam, and laboratory findings-just as will be expected when you practice medicine in the future.

questions.text: Median weight of 100 children was 12 kgs. The standard deviation was 3. Calculate the percent coefficient of variance :
questions.solution: COV = SD/ mean * 100; for normal data mean = median = mode so same formula will apply COV = 3/ 12 * 100 = 25%

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman with a history of systemic hypertension presents to her local emergency department with 2 weeks of right jaw pain that now has developed an area of purulent drainage into her mouth. She reports an accompanying fever. She denies recent dental work. Aside from osteoporosis, she is healthy. Her only medications are alendronate and lisinopril. Physical examination is notable for a temperature of 101.1°F, right-sided facial swelling, diffuse mandibular tenderness, and an area of yellow purulent drainage through the buccal mucosa on the right side. Microscopic examination of the purulent secretions is likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of osteonecrosis of her jaw possibly caused by bisphosphonate use. Additionally, her jaw pain has progressed and now appears to be infected. Actinomyces is a classic oral organism with a propensity to infect the jaw, particularly when the bone is abnormal, usually because of radiation or osteonecrosis.

Oral actinomycosis caused by Actinomyces:

  • Actinomyces is a Gram-positive anaerobe that is not acid fast.
  • Branching filamentous structures.

Oral actinomycosis has a triad of:

1. Sinus

2. Swelling

3. Sulphur granules

Most common site – cervicofacial

-When Sulphur granules crush and see them under microscope there is sun ray appearance.

-Drug of choice: Penicilin.

Answers to other options:

Auer rods are found in acute promyelocytic leukemia.

Although parotitis with obstruction caused by sialolith is possible, the symptoms are in the jaw and diffuse, not specifically involving the parotid gland, thus making sialolith less likely.

questions.text: A 35year old male was admitted with the complains of acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia after consumption of hamburger from a restaurant. The clinician suspected it as Hemolytic-uremic Syndrome. Lab diagnosis revealed EHEC. Which is the most common toxin type responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
EHEC Serotypes O157:H7 and O26:H1 commonly cause HUS.

  • These strains produce Shiga toxins (i.e., Stx-l, Stx-2, or both), which are primarily responsible for the diarrheal diseases.
  • Stx-2 is most commonly associated with HUS, a disorder characterized by acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia.
  • Stx-2 destroys glomerular endothelial cells, resulting in reduced glomerular filtration and acute renal failure.

EHEC:

• EHEC is usually transmitted by contaminated food, i.e. lettuce, spinach, sprouts and undercooked ground beef.

• Low infective dose (< 102CFU) of EHEC can also initiate the infection.

Pathogenesis:EHEC secretes a toxin calledverocytotoxin or Shiga-like toxin.

Causes:

  • HC (hemorrhagic colitis):Manifests as gross bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain and fecal leukocytosis but no fever.
  • Hemorrhagic uremic syndrome (HUS): bloody diarrhea, thrombocytopenia, renal failure and encephalopathy but without fever. It is more common in children.

Diagnosis:

  • Sorbitol MacConkey agar: EHEC in contrast to other E.coli, does not ferment sorbitol.
  • Toxin detection:Cytotoxicity in Vero cell lines (gold standard method).
  • Fecal toxin antigen detection by ELISA or rapid tests.
  • PCR can be used to detect gene coding for VT.

questions.text: A newly married husband is diagnosed with Hepatitis B and C infection. What advice should be given to his wife?

choices.text: Wife to be informed only after consent obtained from husband
Wife should be informed about this as it is sexually transmitted
Wife should be informed due to familial concern

questions.solution: Hepatitis B and C can be sexually transmitted. Hence the wife needs to be informed . there is no need of consent from the husband inorder to inform the wife.

questions.text: This inhibitor of bacterial protein synthesis has a narrow spectrum of antibacterial activity. It has been used in the management of abdominal abscess caused by Bacteroides fragilis, but antibiotic associated colitis has occurred. Which of the following drugs i8 being described?
questions.solution:
Important points about clindamycin are:

  • It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis (via. inhibition of translocation).
  • It is effective against anaerobic organisms.
  • Pseudomembranous colitis and hepatotoxicity are important adverse effects.
  • It is secreted in bile, therefore can be used safely in patients with renal dysfunction. Thus, D is correct.

questions.text: The bodies of the 2 students who had been swept away by a flash flood have been recovered. The body of the first has been found washed up on the bank near a field. The second had been washed further down and was seen among the vegetation of the marshes near the mouth of the river. What is the major factor that influences the onset and duration of algor mortis?

choices.text: The damage sustained by the tissues

questions.solution:
Option B: Environmental temperature

  • Environmental temperature is the major factor that influences the onset and duration of algor mortis.
  • The rate of fall of body temperature is directly proportional to the difference between the temperature of the dead body and the environmental temperature.

Option A: Muscle built of the person

  • Muscle built of the person is not the major factor that influences the onset and duration of algor mortis.
  • Obese bodies cool slowly, and lean bodies rapidly, since fat is a bad conductor of heat.

Option C: The damage sustained by the tissues

  • The damage sustained by the tissues is not the major factor that influences the onset and duration of algor mortis.

Option D: Age

  • Age: The rate of loss of heat is more in children and the elderly, compared to adults because the surface area of the body is more in relation to the body volume.
  • Thus age is not the major factor that influences the onset and duration of algor mortis.

questions.text: While performing a rapid sequence intubation in the operation theatre, a patient was given a standard intravenous dose of muscle relaxant "A". To maintain the muscle relaxation during surgery, another muscle relaxant Vecuronium was given. At the end of the surgery, neostigmine was used to reverse the residual muscle relaxation. However, the patient did not respond and continued to display too much muscle paralysis to permit safe extubation. Drug A was most likely to be?
questions.solution: There are two clues to the answer in this scenario. • The patient underwent rapid sequence intubation (RSI). A depolarizing neuromuscular blocking drug is commonly administered for RSI, because • onset of action is generally more rapid (within 60 seconds) than for most available non depolarizing blockers. • The patient still exhibits residual muscle paralysis even after neostigmine, an anti-cholinesterase. The persistence of paralysis indicates that Drug A is • a depolarizing blocker. Anticholinesterases do not reverse the action of depolarizing and may, in fact, enhance them. • The only depolarizing blocker listed among the options is succinylcholine. In patients with atypical pseudo cholinesterase, SCh may produce prolonged paralysis and apnea. Thus, option D is correct.

questions.text: A foul-smelling vaginal discharge that emits a fishy odor on contact with 10% potassium hydroxide and that demonstrates clue cells on the wet preparation is most likely to be due to:
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Bacterial vaginosis due to G. vaginalis .

Amsel's criteria is used for diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis although Nugent scoring can also be used.

BACTERIAL VAGINOSIS is caused by:

  • Gardanella vaginalis
  • Mobiluncus
  • Provetella

AMSEL’S CRITERIA:

    • pH > 4.5
    • WHIFF TEST→ Discharge + 10% KOH → Fishy odour.
    • CLUE CELLS→ Epithelial cells with bacteria. (See the image below)
    • Homogenous discharge.

Nugen's criteria:

  • for Bacterial Vaginosis.
  • Grading of replacement of normal Flora of vagina by Pathogenic Organisms.

Treatment in non pregnant women is with metronidazole.

questions.text: A compound X decreases the functional activities of several CNS neurotransmitters including dopamine, adrenaline and serotonin at high doses it may cause Parkinsonism like extrapyramidal system dysfunction. Which of the following can be X?
questions.solution: Neurotransmitters (like dopamine, serotonin and adrenaline) are stored in the vesicles after their synthesis. These stores of neurotransmitters are released on stimulation of the neuron. Reserpine inhibits the vesicular transport of these neurotransmitters resulting in depletion of dopamine, serotonin and adrenaline. Severe depression (due to deficiency of serotonin) leading to suicidal tendencies and extrapyramidal symptoms (due to deficiency of dopa-mine in the brain) are the adverse effects of this drug. Thus, option A is correct.

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student with a history of Streptococcal pharyngitis comes to the clinic reporting that he has been ill for 2 weeks. Last week, he developed low-grade fevers, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes in his neck. Over the past 2 days, he has developed a worsening slightly itchy rash as shown in Figure. His physical examination is notable for a temperature of 38.1°C, pharyngeal erythema, bilateral tonsillar enlargement without exudates, bilateral tender cervical adenopathy, and a palpable spleen. All of the following statements regarding his illness are true EXCEPT:

choices.text: Greater than 10% atypical lymphocytosis is likely.
Heterophile antibody testing will likely be diagnostic.
If the heterophile antibody test result is negative, testing for IgG antibodies against viral capsid antigen will likely be diagnostic.
It is spread via contaminated saliva.

questions.solution:
Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is the cause of heterophile-positive infectious mononucleosis (IM), which is characterized by fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, and atypical lymphocytosis.

Paul Bunnell test:

Paul Bunnell test isheterophile agglutination testused for diagnosisof infectious mononucleosis,which is caused byEBV (Epstein–Barr virus).

Theseheterophilic antibodies are IgM antibodies produced in response to EBV infection, that recognize and cross react with Paul–Bunnell antigen on sheep, horse, and bovine RBCs.

Therefore, serum from patients with acute mononucleosis agglutinates sheep, horse, or bovine erythrocytes.

Heterophile antibody testing results will be positive in up to 40% of cases of IM in the first week of illness and up to 90% by the third week.

If heterophile antibody testing results are negative, the more expensive testing for immunoglobulin M (IgM) antibodies to viral capsid antigen are more sensitive and specific.

EBV (Epstein Barr Virus) causes:

  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Naso pharyngeal carcinoma
  • Burkitts lymphoma
  • Hodgkin’s lymphoma / Non Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Tonsillar carcinoma
  • Duncan syndrome.
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia.

The virus is spread by contaminated saliva.

Lab diagnosis:

  • White blood cell count is usually elevated and peaks at 10,000 to 20,000/μL. during the second or third week of illness. Lymphocytosis is usually demonstrable, with greater than 10% atypical lymphocytes.
  • PCR for EBNA (Epstein Barr Nucleic acid)
  • PCR For VCA (Viral capsid antigen)
  • ELISA For EBV

questions.text: A diagnostic test for a particular disease has a sensitivity of 0.90 and a specificity of 0.80 . A single test is applied to each subject in the population in which the disease population is 30% what is the probability that a person . Negative to this test has no disease :
questions.solution:
Positive Gold Standard
Screening Test Negative Total
Positive 27 14 41
Negative 3 56 59
Total 30 70 100

questions.text: A 25-years-old female came to OPD 1 year after postpartum. She was treated for iron deficiency anemia while pregnancy. Now she is pale and her HB was 5% and reticulocyte count was 9%. Her corrected retic count is?
questions.solution: Corrected reticulocyte count=(reticulocyte%× hemoglobin)/15
