questions.text: A 50 year –old woman was found to have a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland. Laboratory findings revealed mild hypothyroidism. A surgical procedure was performed. A photomicrograph of the surgical specimen. The likeliest diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• In lymphocytic thyroiditis (Hashimoto’s disease) , the gland is diffusely enlarged and firm.
  • The acini are almost replaced by great numbers of lymphocytes, often gathered together to form lymph follicles.
  • The surviving acinar epithelium usuallyis pale and eosinophilic. Lymphocytic thyroiditis is considered to be an auto-immune disorder.
  • Almost all patients have circulating antibodies against thyroglobulin and microsomal antigens of thyroid cells. It occurs inwomen in over 95 percent of the cases, especially at the menopause.

questions.text: A doctor is taking history from arthritis patient and decides to make a chart to assess joint involvement. Which chart should he make?
questions.solution: Out of the options best answer is D; as doctor can draw a tree diagram to depict the progression of joint involvement

questions.text: There were 50 patients in a ward20 girls and 30 boys of them 10 girls and 20 boys required surgery . What is the probability of each patient being selectedcorrectlyfor surgery :
questions.solution: There are total 30 patients needing surgery out of 50 patients (boys & girls have been given to confuse)

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis, but the treating intern gave only insulin rapidly to lower blood glucose. What complication is expected by this
questions.solution:
In diabetic ketoacidosis

  • Up to 400 mEq of K+ may be lost in urine during ketoacidosis,
  • Serum K+ is usually normal due to exchange with intercellular stores
  • When insulin therapy is instituted ketosis subsides
  • K+ is driven back intracellularly leading to dangerous hypokalemia
  • After 4 hours it is appropriate to add 10-20 mEq/hr KCI to the i.v. fluid
  • The further rate of infusion is guided by serum K+ measurements and ECG Thus, option B is correct.

questions.text: A child was operated on for small intestine mass with intussusception and after the operation, the tumor was diagnosedin the histological section. Which is the most likely tumor-associated?
questions.solution: This question talks about a child who was operated on for intussusception and was diagnosed intraoperatively as having a mass. It will most probably be a lymphoma as it will manifest as enlarged lymph nodes in the bowel wall which can serve as a lead point for the formation of intussusception Option A is carcinoid manifests as a systemic alteration and less likely to present as an intussusception. Options B and D can give rise to intussusception but are not common in children.

questions.text: A man comes to the emergency with a stab injury to the left flank. He has stable vitals. What would be the next step in management?
questions.solution: The main thing which we look in case of penetrating injury is hemodynamic stability. If the patient is hemodynamically unstable then the patient needs to be taken for emergency exploratory laparotomy. If the patient is hemodynamically stable with no signs of peritonitis or evisceration then we need to subject the patient to CECT to get a better understanding of any significant intraabdominal injury. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage is done in cases of blunt abdominal trauma when FAST results are equivocal. DPL gives the idea of intra peritoneal fluid or blood collection and helps the surgeon to decide whether to operate the person or not. Laparotomy is done in hemodynamically unstable patients, those with signs of peritonitis or any evisceration of the organ. Laparoscopy has no role in acute trauma.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man is admitted to your hemodialysis unit after inpatient hemodialysis initiation for ESRD secondary to FSGS. In your initial evaluation, you obtain a detailed family history in which the patient discloses that his maternal grandfather, mother, and two brothers have all received dialysis. You suspect familial FSGS as the cause of renal disease in this family. Based on the pattern of kidney disease occurrence in his family, what mode of inheritance would you suspect in this patient?

A 72-year-old man without a prior history presents with a recent history of cognitive deficits. The patient has had a stable level of consciousness and denies any current or past substance abuse.The medical chart reveals a history of megaloblastic anemia and a subtotal gastrectomy for severe peptic ulcer disease. Which of the following initial interventions is most appropriate?

choices.text: Order a reversible workup for dementia
Obtain a forensic examination to evaluate competency.

questions.solution:
• Dementia is an organic and global decline of functioning without impaired consciousness.(This differentiates it from delirium characterized by a waxing and waning consciousness.)
  • Themost common type of dementia(50–60%) is theAlzheimer type. Vasculardementia is the second most common type of dementia, occurring in 10–20% of cases. Other degenerative processes that cause dementia are Parkinson disease, Huntington disease, and Pick disease.
  • Infectious, metabolic, endocrine, neoplastic, and toxic processescan also cause dementia. In this case, the history of cognitive decline without impaired consciousness suggests a diagnosis of dementia.
  • The history reveals a megaloblastic anemia, the cause of which may be a vitamin B12 deficiency possiblysecondary to a subtotal gastrectomy.Folate deficiency can also cause megaloblastic anemia.
  • Vitamin deficiencies such as B12 and folatecan cause clinical signs of dementia but represent one of a few possible reversible causes of this process.
  • Acomplete reversible workup for dementiashould also include thyroid function studies and a rapid plasma regain to test for syphilis. Alzheimer disease is confirmed only by autopsy.

questions.text: The sonographic tip of the iceberg sign corresponds to the site within the following tumor, pathologically what is the name of this area?
questions.solution:
Mature teratoma—T is benign tumor contains mature forms of the three germ cell layers:

  1. Mature cystic teratoma develops into a cyst, is common, and is also called benign cystic teratoma or dermoid cyst.
  2. Mature solid teratoma has elements formed into a solid mass.
  3. Fetiform teratoma or homunculus forms a doll-shape, as the germ cell layers display considerable normal spatial differentiation. Of these teratoma types, mature cystic teratoma is by far the most common. These benign tumors comprise approximately 10 to 25 percent of all ovarian neoplasms When sectioned, most cysts appear unilocular and typically contain one area of localized growth, which protrudes into the cystic cavity. Alternatively designated as Rokitansky protuberance, dermoid plug, dermoid process, dermoid mamilla, or embryonal rudiment, this protuberance can be absent or multiple.

questions.text: A 13-year-old female presents with the complaint that she cannot move her right leg. There are no other associated symptoms and no history of trauma, headache, or prior medical problems. The symptom began on the day she was to meet her father for the first time. Which of the following would be least helpful in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Tell her that nothing is wrong
Reassure the patient that she will walk again

questions.solution:
• Management of conversion reactions includes ruling out organic pathology, reassurance, removing precipitating factors, and psychiatric referral.
  • In refractory cases, hypnosis or amobarbital (Amytal) interview may be required.Patients should not be confronted because they are unaware that the symptoms have no organic cause.
  • The Hoover test is useful to distinguish pseudoparalysis from paralysis.The examiner holds the heels of the patient and asks the patient to lift the unaffected leg.
  • With pseudoparalysis, the affected leg will push downward.

questions.text: A 72-year-old asthmatic man comes in for the management of stable exertional angina that he has had for 2 years. Which of the following treatments for managing angina is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
• This patient has two medical problems: asthma andchronic stable angina. Available antianginal drugs are classified as (1) nitrates, (2) β blockers, and (3) calcium-channel blockers.
  • The presence of asthma constitutes acontraindication for the use of noncardioselective –blockers.
  • Adrenergic antagonistscan induce acute episodes of asthma and regularly produceairway obstruction in asthmatics.
  • Even the selective β–adrenergic antagonists do this, particularly at high doses.
  • At low doses, cardioselective –blockers may be used with caution. Calcium-channelblockers and nitrates can also be used to treat this patient.

questions.text: Kumar 1½-year-old child accidentally drinks kerosene mistaking it for water. After 6 hours he developed a cough,tachypnea, and retractions. In the emergency department, the first step in management is –

choices.text: Connect pulse oximeter & perform ABG if needed.

questions.solution: Since kerosene is a volatile poison, aspiration pneumonitis can develop even with ingestion without obvious aspiration. These children need monitoring for the early development of pneumonia. Gastric lavage and inducing vomiting should be avoided.

questions.text: A politician was shot by a gun in the back in a political rally at the T8 level, after which he developed paraplegia. The fact that the injured nerve is not able to regenerate is due to all the reasons except:
questions.solution: All the above-mentioned options inhibit nerve regeneration except lack of myelin inhibitors.

questions.text: A pole vaulter had a fall during pole vaulting and had paralysis of the arm. Which of the following investigations gives the best recovery prognosis?
questions.solution:
Solutions: -

EMG (electromyography) is by far the most reliable and effective test to predict nerve recovery.

Diagnostic Tests for Nerve Injuries:

  • EMG: Denervation fibrillation potentials. Appears at 2–3 weeks then spontaneous fibrillation.
  • EMG is the earliest indicator of nerve recovery.
  • Nerve conduction study:
  1. reduced in axonotmesis and neurotmesis but cannot differentiate between the 2.
  2. Normal nerve conduction velocity on day 10 goes toward neuropraxia.
  3. No conduction will indicate neurotmesis.
  • Sweat Test:
  1. In the autonomous area, the presence of sweat rules out complete injury as sweat fibers are most resistant to compression.
  • MRI: Value only in nerve root lesions (e.g. Brachial plexus injuries).

questions.text: A young male is brought unconscious to the hospital with external injuries. CT brain showed no midline shift but multiple tiny haemorrhages in the brain . What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. occurs due to shearing of white matter
  2. occurs mainly because of rotational acceleration - shows multiple petechial hemorrhages; usually at the junction of white and grey matter
  3. CT Scan may be normal in some cases. so, MRI is the investigation of choice MRI is the preferred investigation in Diffuse Axonal Injury.
  • Young patient with RTA→ NCCT- normal/ Petechial hemorrhages→ Suspect Diffuse axonal injury→MRI (IOC for DAI)

questions.text: A 58-year-old female has a history of breast cancer surgery done. She is a nonsmoker, nonalcoholic. She develops rapid onset bilateral painful proptosis. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution: The most common cause of unilateral (and bilateral) proptosis is a thyroid eye disease. TED is most common in middle-aged females and smoking is an important risk factor. Metastatic deposits in the orbit can lead to proptosis. Hence is the most appropriate answer here.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2 at 8 weeks gestation presents to your clinic reporting painless vaginal bleeding. Her vital signs are as follows: T = 99.9, BP = 162/94, P = 100, and R = 18. Her uterus is consistent with a 14-week pregnancy. Her serum β-hCG level is 320,000 IU/1. Which of the following endocrine glands is most likely to be affected by β-hCG?
questions.solution:
• The clinical scenario (i.e., vaginal bleeding, early pregnancy-induced hypertension, enlarged uterus, and exaggerated β -hCG levels) is consistent with a molar pregnancy.
  • Because of morphologic similarities between hCG and TSH (the alpha subunit is homologous to the alpha subunit of TSH), hCG possesses TSH-like properties and can cause hyperthyroidism.
  • The other endocrine glands are not affected by a molar pregnancy

questions.text: An anesthesia provider is preparing to emerge and extubate a patient after an uncomplicated, successful surgery. The patient has a regular and spontaneous ventilatory pattern and had neuromuscular blockade fully reversed. Maintenance of anesthesia was achieved with 1.0 MAC sevoflurane, which has since been turned off and replaced with high-flow oxygen. Despite this, the patient fails to emerge from anesthesia. The monitors display the following information: Heart rate 70/min, blood pressure 110/60 mmHg, respirations 12/min, temperature 98.0F, SpO2 99%. Inspiratory sevoflurane 0.4%, expiratory sevoflurane 0.5%, inspiratory CO2 0 mmHg, expiratory CO2 40 mmHg. Which of the following breathing circuit components is most likely responsible for the patient’s prolonged emergence?
questions.solution:
• Granules of certain absorbent material have been known to absorb both CO2 and volatile anesthetics.
  • Absorption of the latter can lead to the accumulation of clinically significant levels of anesthetic agent which is later released, despite fresh gas flows being optimized for emergence.
  • The elevated inspiratory concentration of sevoflurane in the setting of high-flow oxygen is suggestive of this.
  • The case was completed successfully with inhaled anesthetic, and the monitor displays lower concentrations of sevoflurane than were previously administered. This suggests that the device is functioning properly.
  • While incompetent expiratory valves could be a source of rebreathable gas, the inspiratory CO2 is not elevated in this case. Exhaled air consists of oxygen, carbon dioxide, and any residual volatile anesthetic.
  • The vaporizer was shut off after maintenance of 1.0 MAC of sevoflurane, and the patient is noted to be inspiring 0.4%.
  • With functioning inspiratory and expiratory valves, the most likely source of sevoflurane would be the CO2 absorbent.

questions.text: A 23-year-old G1P0 woman at 38 weeks’ gestation delivered a 3.2 kg baby boy vaginally. Upon delivery of the placenta, there was noted to be an inverted uterus, which was successfully managed including replacement of the uterus. Which of the following placental implantation sites would most likely predispose to an inverted uterus?
questions.solution: Fundally implanted placenta predisposes to uterine inversion. A placenta implanted in either the anterior, posterior, lateral, or lower segment of the uterus does not have the direct angle that a fundally implanted placenta has through the cervix and out the vagina. The best method for preventing inversion is to await spontaneous separation of the placenta from the uterus before placing traction on the umbilical cord.

questions.text: A five yr old male child has multiple hyperpigmented macules over the trunk. On rubbing the lesion with the rounded end of a pen, he developed urticarial wheal, confined to the border of the lesion. The most likely diagnosis is.
questions.solution: The question is describing darier’s sign. Urticaria pigmentosa (UP) is the commonest presentation of cutaneous mastocytosis. Urticaria pigmentosa is composed of persistent brown or red marks, made of collections of mast cells that swell and itch transiently when rubbed, similar to a hive. In the majority of cases, urticaria pigmentosa may cause skin symptoms but does not progress to more serious types of mastocytosis. If urticaria pigmentosa marks are rubbed firmly, the mast cells release histamine causing them to become itchy, swollen and, occasionally, blistered. This is known as Darier’s sign and is very characteristic of urticaria pigmentosa.

questions.text: A 50 years old woman presents with visual loss. Examination reveals retinal detachment and an ocular lesion. On MRI, the lesion is hyperintense on Tl and hypointense on T2 relative to the vitreous. The lesion enhances postgadolinium injection. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: For all brain tumours, best investigation is contrast enhanced MRI. Melanoma – hypointense on T?Wt MRI & hyperintense on T?Wt MRI due to magnetic property of melanin.

questions.text: Multiple intrahepatic bile duct dilation with bile lakes and concurrent sepsis is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
CAROLI'S DISEASE (TYPE V CHOLEDOCHAL CYST)

  • Congenital malformation consists of multiple saccular dilatations limited to the intrahepatic bile ducts (segmental bile ducts).
  • About half the cases are associated with congenital hepatic fibrosis (affects interlobular bile ducts).
  • Cyst with congenital hepatic fibrosis is known as Grumbach?s disease.
  • Portal hypertension is present in Caroli's disease associated with congenital hepatic fibrosis. Option D is not the answer as klatskin tumor manifests as a lesion at the hilar confluence and not as the intrahepatic lesion. Option B is not the answer as in agile syndrome we have liver damage caused by abnormalities in the bile duct. In this bile builds up in the liver and causes scarring that prevents the liver from working properly to eliminate waste from the bloodstream.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl arrived at class immediately after cross-country running practice. While sitting at her desk, she felt sweaty, warm all over, and nauseated. She then slumped forward with fast, jerklike movements of her arms and legs. Her teacher rushed over to lower her to the floor, and she quickly began to rouse. She initially appeared confused but was able to answer questions appropriately. She had some urinary incontinence during the episode but no tongue trauma. She returned to her baseline mental status within a few minutes of the episode but was taken to the emergency room nonetheless. What is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.solution: The case is consistent with convulsive syncope, based on the history of recent vigorous exercise, a prodrome of nausea and diaphoresis, and loss of consciousness. Additional components of her presentation that suggest a syncopal etiology rather than seizure include the brevity of her loss of consciousness, the brevity of the postictal confusion, and the fast, jerklike movements that were likely myoclonus. Note that there was no mention of repetitive or stereotyped movement before losing consciousness that would suggest automatisms or tonic/clonic activity. There was a loss of bladder control during the episode, but this can occur with any alteration in consciousness. There is nothing in the question stem that would indicate a nonepileptic spell. The diagnostic workup for syncope would generally include orthostatic vital signs, an electrocardiogram, Holter monitor, and/or transthoracic echocardiogram if there is a high suspicion of a cardiac etiology. If events are recurrent, an electroencephalogram may also be considered in case of an atypical seizure presentation. Treatment for the case presented would likely include volume resuscitation, with no other definitive therapy indicated unless there are abnormalities on evaluation. If the patient suffers recurrent syncope, both conservative measures (i.e. compression stockings, abdominal binders, liberalization of salt intake, moving legs before standing) and pharmacological measures (i.e. fludrocortisone).

questions.text: A 75-year-old man with hepatitis C cirrhosis presents for an annual checkup. He denies any new complaints, including jaundice, abdominal pain, ascites, gastrointestinal bleeding, or encephalopathy. Temperature is 99.1°F, pulse 85 beats/ min, blood pressure 109/78 mmHg, respiratory rate 18 breaths/min, and saturation 98% on room air. What studies should be ordered?
questions.solution: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is among the most common cancers worldwide. Anyone with cirrhosis is at risk, and some etiologies of cirrhosis are independent risk factors separate from cirrhosis. For example, in hepatitis B infection, HCC can develop without underlying cirrhosis. Other populations at risk include patients with hepatitis C, alcoholic liver disease, hemochromatosis, alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency, primary sclerosing cholangitis, aflatoxins, HA, anabolic steroid use, and pesticides. HCC screening is therefore recommended in all individuals with cirrhosis. The recommended screening method is ultrasonography every 6 months. Ultrasonography is 60%–90% sensitive, depending on the size of the lesions. Adding AFP testing is no longer recommended due to its cost and false-positive rates.

questions.text: A patient suffering from bipolar disorder, getting episodes of mania and depression, because of poor compliance to drugs, psychotherapy of choice?
questions.solution:
Principles in the treatment of Bipolar Disorders :

  • Maintain dual treatment focus (1) cute short term and (2) prophylaxis .
  • Mania as medical emergency . Treat first, chemistries later .
  • Load valproate and lithium ; titrate lamotrigine slowly .
  • Careful combination treatment can decrease adverse effects .
  • Augment rather than substitute in treatment-resistant patient.
  • Retain lithium in regimen for its antisuicide and neuroprotective effects.
  • Taper lithium slowly, if at all.
  • Educate patient and family about illness and risks to benefit ratios of acute and prophylactic treatments.
  • Give statistics (i.e, 50 percent relapse in first 5 months off lithium ).
  • Assess compliance and suicdality regularly .
  • Develop an early warning system for identification and treatment of emergent symptoms.
  • Contract with patient as needed for suicide and substance use avoidance.
  • Use regular visits : monitor course and adverse effects
  • In quire about and address comborbid alcohol and substance abuse.
  • Targeted psychotherapy: use medicalization of illness.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with ASCVD is complaining of palpitations for the last 4 hours. On examination, her heart rate is 180/min with BP= 90/60 mmHg. Neck veins are full. On auscultation, carotid artery Bruit is present with loud S1 and narrow split S2. The chest has bilateral basal crepitations. Which of the following is not recommended for this patient?
questions.solution:
• ECG showsnarrow complex tachycardiawith an HR of approximately 180/min.
  • P waves are absent.
  • RR interval is reduced and regular.
  • ST-segment depression is noted in most leads.
  • The diagnosis isPSVT.
  • First-line management: Carotid sinus massage.
Carotid sinus massageiscontraindicated in carotid artery bruit.
  • Known case ofASCVD(Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease)andatherosclerotic narrowing of the carotid artery(Carotid artery bruit).
  • If carotid sinus massage is given to this patient it can lead tothe development of embolic strokedue to physical damage to atherosclerotic plaque in the carotid artery.
  • Adenosinewill restore normal sinus rhythm.
  • If it is unsuccessful,DC cardioversionis indicated.

AbsoluteContraindicationstocarotid sinus massageinclude:

  1. MI
  2. TIA or stroke within the preceding three months.
  3. H/O ventricular fibrillation or tachycardia.

questions.text: 14 years old Ramesh presents with pain over the bridge of the nose radiating to the occipital region.Examination revealed swelling of the middle turbinate with postnasal discharge. Involvement of which of the following para-nasal sinus is suspected.
questions.solution: The sphenoid sinus is one of the four paired paranasal sinuses that is contained within the body of the sphenoid bone. The sphenoid sinuses vary in size and shape, and owing to the lateral displacement of the intervening septum, which may insert on the carotid canal, they are rarely symmetrical. They cannot be palpated during an extraoral examination A potential complication of sphenoidal sinusitis is cavernous sinus thrombosis. If a fast-growing tumor erodes the floor of the sinus, the vidian nerve could be in danger. If the tumor spreads laterally, the cavernous sinus and all its constituent nerves could be in danger. An endonasal surgical procedure called a sphenoidotomy may be carried out to enlarge the sphenoid sinus, usually to drain it.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl complained of anxiety and excessive sweating. Investigations showed:
TSH concentration 0.9 mU/L (0.5-3.4)
Free T4 concentration 16 pmol/L (10-18)
Total T4 concentration 180 nmol/L (55-145)
Free T3 concentration 8.2 pmol/L (3.5-10.5)
Total T3 concentration 3.3 nmol/L (0.9-2.5)
These results are compatiblewith one of the following diagnoses?
questions.solution:
• The patient hasa normal TSH and normal free T3 and T4 concentrations, excluding thyrotoxicosis but elevated Total concentrations suggesting a rise in the bindingglobulins. This can occur in pregnancy.
  • Sick euthyroidism would be typically associated with low thyroid hormone concentrations.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with a large untreated boil on the right thigh comes in septic shock. He is started on IV fluids & after giving 3 NS boluses, he develops basal crepitations but the shock continues. He is also administered a dose of Hydrocortisone & started on Dopamine infusion. Currently he is on Dopamine infusion @ 20 micrograms/kg/min. What is the next therapy to consider?
questions.solution:
This is a child with septic shock. The shock is resistant to fluids & Dopamine. The next best step will be to add IV norepinephrine to this patient. Always remember: - Any shock, start with IV fluids; Normal saline preferred; max 3 doses of 20 ml/kg each

- Move to dopamine @ 10-20 microgram per kg per min

- If still in shock, Add Epinephrine in cold shock & Add Norepinephrine in warm/septic shock

- Hydrocortisone & IV antibiotics additionally in septic shock.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady has come to you for assessment of infertility and you are planning an endometrial biopsy of her. On which day do you want to plan the procedure if she has regular menstrual cycles?
questions.solution: Endometrial biopsy is the best ovulation test but it is an invasive method It is done a few days before the expected days of menses. A finding of secretory changes in the endometrium is evidence of progesterone change and hence ovulation Endometrial biopsy is also used for making a diagnosis of luteal phase defect The diagnosis is made by an out of phase endometrium that is more than 2 day lag between menstrual and histological dating. The other uses of endometrial biopsy are - Abnormal uterine bleeding - Postmenopausal bleeding - Evaluation of amenorrhoea the possible complications may include bleeding, pelvic infection, and puncture of the uterine wall.

questions.text: A neonate delivered at term was noticed to have multiple violet-black macules on the back and thigh since birth, as shown in the picture. Which among the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: May represent neural crest migration defect
May be associated with Hurler syndrome

questions.solution: This is a neonate showing Mongolian spots. They are a self-limited neural crest migration defect and occur in normal neonates, slowly fading with age. Extensive spots may occur in Hurler syndrome. They do not require any therapy.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman books at 17 weeks and requests screening for Down’s syndrome. Which of the following tests would be suitable for Down’s syndrome screening?
questions.solution: Screening for Downs syndrome: The “combined test” (nuchal translucency, beta-human chorionic gonadotrophin pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A) should be odered to all women to screen for Down’s syndrome between 11 weeks+ 0 days and 13 weeks and 6 days. For women who book after these dates, serum screening (triple or quadruple test) should be odered between 15 weeks + 0 days and 20 weeks + 0 days.

questions.text: High inguinal orchidectomy specimen showed tumor testis with the involvement of epididymis without vascular invasion; the stage is:
questions.solution:
7thAJCC (2010) TNM staging for testicular tumors
T: Primary tumor N: Regional lymph nodes
pTis : Intratubular germ cell neoplasia ( carcinoma in situ) N1: LN mass ≤2 cm or multiple LN masses, none >2 com
pT1: Limited to the testis and epididymis and no vascular/lymphatic invasion N2: LN mass, >2 cm but <5 cm or multiple LN masses, any one mass > 2 cm but not <5 cm
pT2: Limited to the testis and epidiymis with vascular/lymphatic invasion or extending through tunica albuginea with involvement of tunica vaginalis N3: LN mass >5 cm
pT3: Invades the spermatic cord with or without vascular /lymphatic invasion M: Distant metastases
pT4: Invades the scrotum with or without vascular/lymphatic invasion M1; Non-regional nodal or pulmonary metastases M2: Non-pulmonary visceral masses

questions.text: A 24-year-old man had multiple small hypopigmented macules on the upper chest and back for last 3 months. The macules were circular, arranged around hair follicles and had coalesced to form large sheets. The surface showed fine scaling. The most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis is

choices.text: Potassium hydroxide preparation of the scales

questions.solution: Potassium hydroxide preparation of the scales Multiple small hypopigmented macules on the upper chest and back with perifollicular location and fine scaling is s/o Pityriasis versicolor.

questions.text: A 31-year-old (gravida 1, para 1) female had a forceps-assisted vaginal delivery 3 months ago. Her infant weighed 4250 g. During the delivery, she sustained a fourth-degree perineal injury that was repaired. She now complains of fecal incontinence and foul vaginal discharge when her stools are loose, which happens several days a week. The most likely etiology for her fecal incontinence and foul vaginal discharge would be which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Maternal obstetric injury remains a major cause of rectovaginal ?fistula in women. For this patient, it is imperative to determine the presence or absence of a concomitant injury to the anal sphincter complex along with the possibility of a fistula.
  • Crohn’s disease can be a cause of abdominal pain, diarrhea, anal abscess formation, and fecal incontinence. It would be very unlikely, and highly coincidental, for it to present in this manner.
  • Neither a vaginal hematoma nor a retained vaginal foreign body would result in fecal incontinence.

questions.text: A 14-year-old old boy presents with a sore throat and macroscopic hematuria. What would light microscopy of a kidney biopsy most likely show?
questions.solution: The most common cause of macroscopic hematuria in a child is IgA nephritis. This usually develops 1-2 days after a sore throat. It is most common in the second and third decades of life and is three times more common in males. The urine may be frankly bloody or maybe the color of cola. There are no clots in the urine, and the hematuria is generally painless, although some patients complain of mild loin pain. It tends to settle spontaneously within 5 days, although the episodes may be recurrent, lasting for one to two years. A renal biopsy will show mesangial IgA deposition on immunofluorescence, and light microscopy will show mesangial hypercellularity and matrix expansion.

questions.text: A 10 years old girl presented with hypokalemia, mild hypercalciuria, hypertension, and metabolic alkalosis. Which among the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of Hypertension, Hypokalemia, Alkalosis, and Hypercalciuria is seen only in Liddle syndrome. Remember that Barter syndrome never shows hypertension and Gitelman syndrome shows hypocalciuria.

  • Liddle syndrome: hypertension, hypokalemia & metabolic alkalosis
  • Gitelman's syndrome: hypokalemia & metabolic alkalosis, hypocalciuria, hypomagnesemia
  • Bartter's syndrome: hypokalemia, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, hypercalciuria with nephrocalcinosis.

questions.text: A 6-year male child has unilateral ptosis of the left eye since birth. The difference between vertical fissures of both eyes (RE-LE) is 3 mm. The levator palpebrae superioris excursion, after negating frontalis action is 6 mm (moderate). The procedure of choice for correcting ptosis is -
questions.solution:
• This child has moderate ptosis with a moderate degree of LPS function. Therefore the procedure of choice is levator resection.
  • Fasanella procedure is for ptosis <2mm with good LPS function. Frontalis suspension is for ptosis >2 mm with poor LPS functions.

questions.text: The most common etiologies of abnormal bleeding have been correctly paired with their age demographic in all except
questions.solution:
AUB refers to menstrual bleeding of abnormal quantity, duration and schedules The most common etiologies of AUB are associated with pregnancy, structural uterine pathologies , anovulation, bleeding disorders or neoplasia The most common cause of abnormal bleeding in adolescence is anovulation followed by bleeding disorders In the childhood age group it is non specific vulvovaginitis In the perimenopausal women it is again anovulation in 80% cases While the most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding is atrophic endometritis or senile endometrial atrophy (worldwide) and in India is cervical cancer. Please note that although endometrial cancer is not the most common cause, it is still important to do an endometrial biopsy in all cases of postmenopausal bleeding.

The classification of abnormal uterine bleeding to be used is PALM-COEIN system The important investigation in all reproductive age woman with abnormal bleeding is urine pregnancy test Other important tests are - Coagulation disorders - Hormonal assessment - Cervical cancer screening - Endometrial sampling if the woman is more than 45 years of age - Pelvic ultrasound - Saline infusion sonography and hysteroscopy.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, G2A1 with history of one ectopic pregnancy, presents to your clinic because she missed her last period. According to her records, 4 years ago her unruptured ectopic was resolved by a linear salpingostomy procedure. You send a serum [beta-hCG level, which returns elevated β-hCG = 900 IU/1). Radiologic images obtained in the emergency department are unremarkable. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Eight days after conception, hCG doubles every 2 to 3 days in normal pregnancy (not in an ectopic or a destined miscarriage).

  • Performing a formal (i.e., performed and interpreted by a radiologist with expertise in ultrasonography) transvaginal ultrasound at a serum β -hCG level less than 1000 IU/1 is not useful because both the fallopian tubes and the uterus appear empty even though a developing embryo may be present.
  • The transvaginal ultrasound is not sensitive enough to detect a gestational sac at hCG levels below 1000 IU/1.
  • The transabdominal ultrasound is even less sensitive. It can detect a gestational sac reliably at hCG levels of less than 6500 IU/1. The qualitative urine hCG is not as sensitive as a quantitative serum [beta- hCG level.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man has a relapsing-remitting type of multiple sclerosis for nearly 20 years with optic neuritis and spastic paraparesis with partial recovery.Patients bladder is likely to reveal which of the following abnormalities?
questions.solution: Patients with multiple sclerosis often develop a spastic(upper motor neuron ) bladder.There is little or no residual urine in the bladder after emptying because bladder contractibility is good but distensibility is poor.The bladder does not distend substantially because of corticospinal disease which produces spasticity. The patient usually has urgency or incontinence.

questions.text: In a 60 old female with polydipsia, ADH obtained are as follows The baseline: Sodium 151 Plasma osmolality 300 Urinary osmolality 150 After Vasopressin: Sodium 142 Potassium 3.9 Plasma osmolality 290 Urinary osmolality 480 These findings suggest a diagnosis of
questions.solution: On ADH stimulation as urine osmolality rises >50% of the baseline is suggestive of ADH deficiency i.e central DI.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to gynecologist with complaints of vaginal discharge. There was no discharge from cervix on speculum examination. The diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis was made based on all the following findings except
questions.solution:
The Ph in Bacterial vaginosis is alkaline and hence there is lesser estrogenic environment and consequently lesser lactobacilli.

  • It is diagnosed on the basis of the following findings :
  • A fishy vaginal odour
  • Vaginal secretions are gray and thinly coat the vaginal walls.
  • pH higher than 4.5 (usually 4.7 to 5.7).
  • Increased number of clue cells,and leukocytes are conspicuously absent.
  • The addition of KOH to the vaginal secretions (the “whiff” test) releases a amine like odor.
  • Alternative diagnostictests such as a pH and amines test card, detection of G.
  • vaginalis ribosomal RNA, or Gram stain

questions.text: In congenital dislocation of hip, clinical sign which shows that the affected thigh is at a higher level when the knees and hips are flexed to 90 degrees is known as
questions.solution: TheGaleazzitest, also known as the Allis sign, is used in the assessment ofcongenital dislocation/developmental dysplasia of the hip. It is performed by flexing an infant's knees in the supine position so that the ankles touch the buttocks. If the knees are not level then the test is positive, indicating a potential congenital hip malformation.

questions.text: A 20-years old male comes to causality with a head injury. Examination reveals normal consciousness and blood in the tympanic membrane. The most likely cause is:
questions.solution: If there is a base of skull fracture blood can trickle down and get collected in the middle ear and if on clinical examination you see blood behind the tympanic membrane it is suggestive of basilar skull fracture. Extradural hemorrhage, Subdural hemorrhage, and intraventricular hemorrhage can not be reliably diagnosed on clinical examination. They can be diagnosed only after we have the NCCT Brain Scan report of the patient.

questions.text: A 55 year old lady presents with flaccid bullae and slow-healing erosions on head and trunk. She also has painful oral erosions. She gives history of similar episode in past which required treatment in hospital. The most likely structure damaged in the patient is
questions.solution: Flaccid bullae, slow-healing erosions on the head and trunk, painful oral erosions suggest a diagnosis of mucocutaneous pemphigus Vulgaris. Anti Dsg1 and Anti Dsg-3 antibodies are responsible.

questions.text: A 59 year old man is diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the lower oesophagus. A contrast enhanced CT of the chest and abdomen demonstrates a right paratracheal lymph node that measures 9 mm in the short axis, with no evidence of distant metastases. The PET-CT demonstrates no uptake in the right paratracheal lymph node, but there is symmetrical uptake of 18-FDG in both supraclavicular areas. What is the most likely explanation for this finding?

choices.text: Recent viral upper respiratory tract infection

questions.solution: Brown fat is well-recognized physiological cause of 18-FDG uptake (the location ans symmetrical distribution are typical) and benzodiazepines can be administered to reduce brown fat uptake. Hyperglycaemia is likely to result in reduced 18-FDG uptake as the radioisotope has to complete with glucose for uptake into metabolically active cells.

questions.text: A 41-years-old male patient presented with recurrent episodes of bloody Diarrhea &mucus for 5 years. Despite regular treatment with adequate doses of sulfasalazine, he has had several exacerbations of his disease and required several weeks of steroids for the control for flares. What should be the next line of treatment for him?
questions.solution:
This clinical presentation is suggestive of steroid-dependent IBD. Steroid sparing drug will be given ie azathioprine.

  • Azathioprine and 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP) are purine analogs commonly employed in the management of glucocorticoid-dependent IBD.
  • Azathioprine is rapidly absorbed and converted to 6-MP, which is then metabolized to the active end product, thioinosinic acid, an inhibitor of purine ribonucleotide synthesis and cell proliferation.
  • These agents also inhibit the immune response. Efficacy can be seen as early as 3-4 weeks but can take up to 4-6 months.

questions.text: A 31-year-old primigravida woman at 12 weeks gestation undergoes a routine transvaginal ultrasound, which reveals twin pregnancies with the placenta displaying a T sign. If the twins were developed from a single zygote, which of the following is the most likely timing of cell division resulting in the twins?
questions.solution:
Option C :T sign is seen in monochorionic diamniotic twins, lambda sign/ Twin peak sign is seen in Dichorionic diamniotic twins

In monozygotic twins, chorionicity depends upon time of cell division. Monochorionic diamniotic twinning is seen when the zygote dives between day 4-8.

Time of cell division Chorionicity of placenta
First 72 hours post fertilization(morula stage) DCDA
4-8th day(blastocyst stage) MCDA(MC type of monozygotic twins)
8-12th day MCMA
>12th day Conjoined/Siamese twins, type of MCMA(fusion of embryonic disc occurs)

questions.text: A 12-year-old patient presented with bleeding from the ear, pain, tinnitus, and increasing deafness. Examination revealed red swelling/mass behind the intact tympanic membrane that blanches on the pressure with a pneumatic speculum. Treatments for her include all except:
questions.solution:
• Glomus tumors can be treated with surgical excision, radiation therapy, surgery, and irradiation, or embolization and surgery.
  • Surgical removal is often associated with a significant intraoperative bleeding rate because of the vascular nature of the tumors, especially when they are large.
  • To reduce intraoperative blood loss, preoperative devascularization with transarterial embolization has proved beneficial, but this often remains incomplete because of the extensive angioarchitecture and substantial arteriovenous shunting of these lesions.
  • Alternatively, direct puncture and the injection of acrylic glue have been described, but these can also be associated with complications.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female college student comes to your office because she developed dark urine after playing basketball. She denies joint symptoms or rash but does recall a sore throat about 1 week before the episodeofdarkurine. Onphysicalexamination, herBPisnormal, andthereisnoedema.Theremainder ofthe examination is normal. Complete blood count, blood urea nitrogen, serum creatinine, serum electrolytes, and serum complement are also normal. Antinuclear Ab assay is negative. Urinalysis shows 1+ protein, many erythrocytes/HPF, and erythrocyte casts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Understand the cause of glomerular proteinuria. This patient has IgA nephropathy. The presence of erythrocyte casts defines the cause of the dark urine and hematuria as glomerular in origin. IgA nephropathy typically presents as dark urine in a young person in association with an upper respiratory tract infection or participation in an athletic event. Although sickle cell disease may be associated with a focal segmental pattern of glomerulosclerosis, this disorder does not cause episodes of dark urine. Hematuria from medullary microinfarcts in patients with sickle cell disease is not of glomerular origin and not associated with erythrocyte casts. Both post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis and lupus nephritis are typically associated with a low serum complement level.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a patient who presents with primary amenorrhoea, absent uterus, scant pubic hair, well-developed breast, and clitoromegaly?
questions.solution: Absent female internal organs with scant pubic hair rule out Mullerian agenesis. In Turner syndrome uterus is present and breast development is absent. This is a case of androgen insensitivity syndrome in complete androgen insensitivity. In partial; AIS the phenotype varies from mild degrees of virilization to fertile but undervirilised men. In complete AIS the genital appearance is completely female external genitalia with short vagina while in partial AIS the external genitalia will show clitoromegaly, narrow vagina, and variable fusion of labia minora In partial AIS the gonads are inguinal at puberty there is breast development and slight virilization but spermatogenesis is absent And we prefer pre-pubertal gonadectomy in partial AIS THE more virilized male phenotype in partial AIS will have hypospadias and bifid scrotum, they will have gynecomastia, the pubic hair is slightly reduced and gonadectomy is not required but surveillance is recommended.

questions.text: A 27 year old female presents with tender subcutaneous nodules on her lower legs.Which of the following is least likely to be the etiology?
questions.solution: The diagnosis is Erythema nodosum.It can occur as a result of Infections(eg:Streptococcal,Fungal,Mycobacterial,Yersinia) ;Drugs(eg:Sulfa drugs,Penicillins,Oral contraceptives) ; Sarcoidosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G1P0 at 8 weeks gestation presents for her first prenatal visit. She has no significant past medical or surgical history. A 29-year-old friend of hers just had a baby with Down syndrome and she is concerned about her risk of having a baby with the same problem. The patient denies any family history of genetic disorders or birth defects. You should tell her that she has an increased risk of having a baby with Down syndrome in which of the following circumstances?

choices.text: The age of the father of the baby is 40 years or older.
Her pregnancy was achieved by induction of ovulation and artificial insemination.
She has had three first-trimester spontaneous abortions

questions.solution: The risk of aneuploidy is increased with multiple miscarriages not attributable to other causes such as endocrine abnormalities or cervical incompetence. Paternal age does not contribute significantly to aneuploidy un l probably age 55, and most risks of paternal age are for point mutations. A 45, X karyotype results from loss of chromosome material and does not involve increased risks for nondisjunction errors. Similarly, induced ovulation does not result in increased nondisjunction, and hypermodel conceptions (triploidy) do not increase the risk for future pregnancies.

questions.text: Your 25-year-old pa ent is pregnant at 36 weeks gestation. She has an acute urinary tract infection (UTI). Of the following medications used in the treatment of UTIs, which is contraindicated in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution: These questions address the ques of teratogenicity.Tetracycline may cause fetal dental anomalies and inhibition of bone growth if administered during the second and third trimesters, and it is a potential teratogen to first-trimester fetuses. Administration of tetracyclines can also cause severe hepatic decompensation in the mother, especially during the third trimester. Chloramphenicol may cause the gray baby syndrome (symptoms of which include vomiting, impaired respiration, hypothermia, and, finally, cardiovascular collapse) in neonates who have received large doses of the drug. No notable adverse effects have been associated with the use of penicillins or cephalosporins. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (Bactrim) should not be used in the third trimester because sulfa drugs can cause kernicterus.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male had burning micturition and urethral discharge. After 4 weeks he developed joint pains involving both the knees and ankles, redness of the eye, and skin lesion, The most probable skin lesion is:
questions.solution: reactive arthritis, is the classic triad of conjunctivitis, urethritis, and arthritis occurring after infection, particularly those in the urogenital or gastrointestinal tract. Dermatologic manifestations are common, including keratoderma blennorrhagicum.

questions.text: A 10-years old boy presented with cervical lymphadenopathy. Needle biopsy from the nodes revealed secondaries from papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. The child underwent complete removal of tumor total thyroidectomy and radical neck dissection. What total thyroidectomy and radical neck dissection. What should be the immediate next line of management?

choices.text: I-131 whole body scan to assess the extent of disease
CECT scan to assess any residual disease

questions.solution: Once you have operated on a patient with papillary carcinoma of the thyroid we need to provide thyroxine externally as we have removed the thyroid tissue and it also helps to suppress any part of the tissue that has been left inside. Then after about 4-6 weeks,the patient becomes euthyroid and then we discontinue thyroxine and put the patient on RAI so that the remaining of the tissue which is left inside is ablated by RAI. And after that, we restart thyroxine and use thyroglobulin as a marker of recurrence. The bone scan is done if the patient has any symptoms, like bone pain. CECT does not help to access any residual disease after thyroidectomy.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male had multiple small hypopigmented macules on the upper chest and back for the last three months. The macules were circular, arranged around follicles and many had coalesced top form large sheets. The surface showed fine scaling. He had similar lesions one year ago which subsided with treatment. The most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis is
questions.solution: Hypopigmented macules on the upper chest and back arranged around follicles with fine scaling indicate pityriasis Versicolor. KOH will show “spaghetti and meatball appearance”.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presented with haematuria with clots was diagnosed as stage II TCC of the urinary bladder. Which of the following statement is true regarding the treatment of this patient?

choices.text: Cystoscopic fulguration is the best treatment
TUR should be followed by intravesical BCG in this case
There is no major role of Radiotherapy
Radical Cystectomy is the best treatment for him

questions.solution:
Stage Initial treatment option
TIS Complete TUR+ Intravesical BCG
Ta (single , low grade, non-recurrent) Complete TUR
Ta (Large, multiple , high grade , recurrent ) TUR+intravesical chemo/immunotherapy
T1 TUR+intravesical chemo/immunotherapy
T2-T4 Radical cystectomy Neoadjuvant chemotherapy + Radical cystectomy Radical cystectomy + adjuvant chemotherapy Neoadjuvant chemotherapy+ concomitant chemo and irradiation Partial cystectomy (Till T3)
Any T, N+ , M+ Systemic chemotherapy + selective surgery or RT

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presented with fresh rectal bleeding and a recent onset of malaise, lethargy, and myalgia, and weight loss of 10 kilograms. 9 years earlier she had a right hemicolectomy to remove a Dukes B adenocarcinoma and 4 years earlier she had an intracerebral hemorrhage. She was referred for an urgent colonoscopy but before this could happen she was admitted to the hospital with worsening symptoms and confusion. On examination, her temperature was 37.7ºC, BP 196/114 mmHg, and her heart sounds were normal. She had bibasal lung crepitations, a raised jugular venous pressure, and there was a tender erythematous rash with 2-5cm lesions over the lower extremities. Other than a laparotomy scar, the abdominal examination was normal. Investigations: Hemoglobin 9.7g/dL (11.5–16.5), Platelet count 598×109/L (150– 400), Serum urea 49mmol/L (2.5–7.0). Serum creatinine 970μmol/L (60–110), Serum C-reactive protein 132mg/L (<10). Antinuclear antibodies negative (negative at 1:20 dilution), Anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies negative. Urinalysis blood 2+, protein 2+. Which investigation is most likely to yield the diagnosis?
questions.solution: She has polyarteritis nodosa. A biopsy may be dangerous / fail to show affected areas.

questions.text: Renal cell carcinoma histopathologically showing 'perinuclear halo' and "Plant like" structure in malignant cells is seen in:
questions.solution: Chromophobe RCC presents as large cells with clear cytoplasm with a thick cell membrane. They have a nucleus with a fine reticular appearance and a perinuclear hallo. These findings are similar to what we get in plant cells so renal cell carcinoma which appears as plant cell is chromophobe type. Option A is wrong as clear cell carcinoma only has a clear cell on histopathology because of washing of the intracellular content while processing the slide. Papillary and collecting duct carcinomas don’t look like plant cells.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient met with a road traffic accident & is brought to the emergency in an unconscious state. CT abdomen reveals a splenic laceration, emergency splenectomy is done & patient is shifted to ICU. His BP remains low in the post-op period even after a bolus of normal saline. O/E- he is afebrile, has a moon-like face with central obesity &the presence of violet striae over the abdomen. A repeat CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis shows no hemorrhage. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Return to the operating room for exploratory laparotomy

questions.solution:
Moon-like facies, central obesity & abdominal striae are signs of glucocorticoid excess - endogenous (Cushing syndrome)/ exogenous.

A physiologic stressor (trauma) may trigger an adrenal crisis.

  • Acute adrenal insufficiencyrequires immediate initiation of rehydration (saline infusion at initial rates of 1 L/hr) with continuous cardiac monitoring.
  • Glucocorticoid replacement- initiated by bolus injection of 100 mg of hydrocortisone, followed by the administration of 100–200 mg of hydrocortisone over 24 hours.
  • Mineralocorticoid replacement can be initiated once the daily hydrocortisone dose is <50 mg as at higher doses, hydrocortisone provides sufficient stimulation of mineralocorticoid receptors.

questions.text: When the rectum is inflated with air through a rectal tube, pain and tenderness occur in the right iliac fossa in case of appendicitis? This is known as:
questions.solution: Bastedo’s sign describes a condition in which if the rectum is inflated with air through rectal tube pain and tenderness occurs in the right iliac fossa in case of acute appendicitis. Aaron’s sign is also present in acute appendicitis and is described as pain occurring on pressing of epigastric region. Battle sign is a feature that we see in the middle cranial fossa base of skull fracture, in this there is a bluish discoloration of the posterior part of the mastoid process. Mc Burney's sign is a feature seen in acute appendicitis and describes a migratory pain in patients of acute appendicitis in the right iliac fossa.

questions.text: A lady presented with recurrent attacks of giddiness and abdominal pain since three months. The endoscopy wasnormal. Her fasting blood glucose was 40 mg% and insulin levels were elevated. CT abdomen showed a well defined8 mm enhancing lesion in the head of the pancreas, with no other abnormal findings. What should be the treatment plan for this patient?
questions.solution: This case scenario describes a patient who has recurrent attacks of giddiness, and abdominal pain for 3 months. Has hypoglycemia with raised insulin levels, CT scan shows an 8 mm lesion in the head of the pancreas. This patient has findings that point towards insulinoma as the diagnosis. This patient should be treated by enucleation. As insulinoma is a benign tumor enucleation is the treatment of choice for insulinoma.

questions.text: A child can self-feed with a spoon without spilling, copy a circle, dress, and undress independently but cannot close and open his buttons. What is the likely age at which this development status is first attained?
questions.solution:
A child learns to self-feed well (without spilling) between 15-18 months of age. He learns to copy a circle at 3 years and can self-dress and undress at 3 years. But independent dressing and undressing including buttons come at 4 years of age. Hence the age of the child is 3 years.

As per nelson AAP

Undressing with support @2 years and dressing with support @ 3 years
Dressing and undressing independently (except closing buttons ) 3 years
Dressing and undressing independently ( including closing button ) 4-5 years

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of increasing swelling of her ankles. There are no preceding symptoms and there is no past medical or drug history of note. She then develops hand and facial swelling and finds her trousers increasingly tight around the waist. She has no rash, joint pains, or other symptoms. On examination, she has gross pitting edema of both legs, ascites, and facial, hand, and sacral edema. Investigations include a chest X-ray (CXR) demonstrating small bilateral pleural effusions. A urine dipstick shows 4+ proteinuria and no blood. A 24-hour urine collection shows 4.2 g/24-hours proteinuria. Her serum creatinine is 67 μmol/l, albumin 16 g/l, and glucose 4 mmol/l. Her cholesterol is 10 mmol/l. What is the most likelydiagnosis?
questions.solution: This woman has nephrotic syndrome (edema, hypoalbuminemia, hypercholesterolemia, and more than 3.5g/24 hours proteinuria). Post-infectious GN and Goodpasture’s syndrome are more likely to present as a nephritic illness with hypertension, hematuria as well as proteinuria, edema, and renal impairment. Good pasture's syndrome would also by definition have a pulmonary hemorrhage. Diabetic nephropathy can present as a nephrotic syndrome but only in longstanding diabetics and this girl has no past medical history and normal serum glucose. Ig3Anephropathyrarely causes nephrotic syndrome and usually has hematuria as well as proteinuria. A renal biopsy would be required to confirm the diagnosis of minimal change disease and the treatment would be steroids.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man has recurrent episodes of hematuria over the past year. Each of the episodes seems to be associated with an upper respiratory infection. Physical examination currently is normal. Urinalysis reveals relatively blandsediment;dipstickispositiveforbothproteinandblood.Renalbiopsymostlikelywillreveal?

choices.text: Diffuse mesangial deposition of IgA onimmunofluorescence

questions.solution: One of the more common forms of asymptomatic urinary abnormalities is Berger’s disease, which may be a cause of recurrent haematuria of glomerular origin. Such episodes of macroscopic hematuria and may be associated with minor flulike illnesses or vigorous exercise. Skin rash, arthritis, and abdominal pain usually are absent, which tends to distinguish this entity from Henöch-Schönlein purpura. Occasionally patients develop a nephrotic or nephritic syndrome. Serum IgA levels are increased in about 50% of all cases, though serum complement is normal. Renal biopsy in these situations may reveal a spectrum of changes, though diffuse mesangial proliferation or focal and segmental proliferative GN is most common. The essential feature of Berger’s disease is the finding of diffuse mesangial deposition of IgA on immunofluorescence microscopy. IgG, C3, and properdin, but not C1q or C4, also may be found in this study. Although the disease progresses slowly, about 50% of patients develop end-stage renal failure within 25 years of the original presentation. Men with hypertension and proteinemia (1 g/d) are most likely to progress. Except for a recent report suggesting that omega-3 fatty acids may play a role, specific therapy has not been useful. However, glucocorticoids or antibiotics may reduce the frequency of episodic gross hematuria. IgA deposition in the kidney and recurrent renal failure may occur in about 35% of those who receive a renal allograft. Fortunately, such recurrent pathologic findings usually are not associated with loss of renal function.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented with mild abdominal pain, mild constipation with a feeling of incomplete evacuation, and mucus in stools for the past 4 years. On examination, tenderness present on the left iliac fossa. Barium enema picture is given below. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
COLONIC DIVERTICULA

  • Mc cause of significant lower GI bleeding: Diverticula
  • Bleeding occurs at the neck of the diverticulum and is believed to be secondary to bleeding from the vasa recti as they penetrate through the submucosa.
  • Of those that bleed, more than 75% stop spontaneously, although about 10% rebleed within 1 year and almost 50% within 10 years.
  • Although diverticular disease is much more common on the left side, the right-sided disease is responsible for more than half of episodes of bleeding.
  • The best method of diagnosis and treatment: Colonoscopy
  • Epinephrine injection, electrocautery, endoscopic clips to control the hemorrhage.
  • If none of these maneuvers is successful or if hemorrhage recurs, Colonic resection is indicated.
  • The mortality rate of emergent subtotal colectomy for bleeding:30%

questions.text: The mother of a 25-year-old man who was diagnosed with AIDS 1 year ago, reports that her son had been doing well until this morning when she observed him sitting up in bed, punching the air and grabbing at insects, although none were present. The patient’s CD4 count is <100 cells/mm3 and his temperature is 103°F. The mother is concerned about these symptoms because the patient’s elder brother has schizophrenia. This clinical picture is most consistent with:
questions.solution: This clinical picture that includes the sudden onset of a psychiatric symptom (i.e., visual hallucinations) coinciding with the onset of a high fever in a relatively recently diagnosed (1 year) AIDS patient is most consistent with delirium caused by an opportunistic infection of the brain such as cryptococcal meningitis. Psychotic illnesses such as schizophrenia, brief psychotic disorder, or AIDS dementia cannot be diagnosed if the symptoms (as in this patient) can be explained by an acute medical illness. Also, AIDS dementia occurs in the late stages of the disease and would be characterized primarily by gradually worsening cognitive functioning (e.g., memory loss) as well as motor symptoms.

questions.text: 50 yrs old male presented with odynophagia, a “hot potato” voice, and stridor.On examination, diffuse swelling over the posterior pharyngeal wall was seen. The X-ray revealed increased retropharyngeal space.Most suspected diagnosis is :
questions.solution: Prevertebral abscess presents with diffuse swelling while retropharyngeal abscess presents with localized swelling.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman presents with a history of several untreated sexually transmitted diseases in the past. Pupils are small and irregular and do not respond to light but respond to accommodation. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• Argyll Robertson's pupil is usually miotic and almost always bilateral.
  • The pupil does not react to light but will react to accommodation. It is suggestive of a neurosyphilis infection that affects the light reflex pathway.
  • The description of a hyperemic and swollen disc is consistent with optic neuritis,which is an inflammation of the optic nerve sometimes seen in patients with multiple sclerosis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old womanpresents to your office with a complaint of severe fatigue, weakness, and dyspnea on exertion.She has had these symptoms for 2 days. The patient denies having fever, chills, weight changes, ordysuria. Her medical history is significant for pernicious anemia and hypothyroidism.Results of thyroid studies were within normal limits 1 week ago. Her physical examination is positive for mild icterus and hepatosplenomegaly. CBCis normal, except for a hematocrit of 21%. Her hematocrit was36% 3 months ago. Liver function tests show the total bilirubin level to be 4.6 mg/dl and the indirect bilirubin level to be 4.2 mg/dl. Other results are within normal limits.A direct Coombs test is positive.Which of the following statements regardingautoimmune hemolytic anemia is true?

choices.text: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia typically results in intravascular hemolysis
Autoimmune hemolytic anemia may be idiopathic or secondary to disorders such as systemic lupus erythematosus, chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), HIV infection, or hepatitis C infection
Most patients with autoimmune hemolytic anemia are cured with steroid therapy
Splenectomy is curative for those patients who do not respond to simple steroid therapy

questions.solution:
• Intravascular hemolysisin autoimmune hemolytic anemia is rare and indicates that an extremely rapid rate of erythrocytedestruction is occurring or that the extravascular removal mechanisms have been overwhelmed.
  • Erythrocytes sensitized to IgG aloneare usually removed in the spleen, whereas RBCs sensitized to IgG plus complement or to complement alone are generally destroyed in the liver becausehepatic Kupffer cells carry receptors specific for complement component C3b.
  • Both an idiopathic variety of autoimmune hemolyticanemia and a variety that occurs secondary to other disorders have been described. Such primary disorders include systemic lupus erythematosus, non-Hodgkin lymphoma (especially chronic lymphocytic leukemia),Hodgkin disease, cancer, myeloma,dermoid cyst, HIV infection, angioimmunoblastic lymphadenopathy with dysproteinemia, hepatitis C infection, and chronic ulcerative colitis.
  • Approximately 20% of patients remain well indefinitely after steroid therapy, but the majority suffer from a chronic, treacherous disease that can produce sudden relapses with abrupt anemia.
  • If thecorticosteroid dose required for long-term therapy produces significant morbidity, one can proceed empirically either to splenectomyor to the use of immunosuppressive agents.
  • Splenectomy rarely results in extended remission but is valuable as a prednisone-sparing measure.

questions.text: A 7 yr old boy presents with appearance of multiple vesicles which enlarged to form flaccid bullae which had purulent contents. When they ruptured they left behind brown crusting. The most likely cause of the disease is:

choices.text: Linear deposition of IgA at the dermoepidermal junction

questions.solution:
A young boy presenting with fluid and pus lesions suggests bullous impetigo which is caused by staph Auto antibodies against desmosomal components- Pemphigus Auto antibodies against hemidesmosomal components- Bullous pemphigoid Linear deposition of IgA at the dermoepidermal junction- Linear IgA disease.

Bullous impetigo

  • Caused byS. aureus
  • S. aureus phage type 2 releases Epidermolytic Toxin (ET).
  • This toxin ruptures desmosomes primarily in subcorneal layer – as the target is desmoglein – 1
  • (Note : It is atoxin- mediated destruction of Dsg – 1, not autoimmune destruction as in pemphigus foliaceus).
  • The organism can be cultured from blister fluid. The pus settles on lower end of the blister as it is heavier –Hypopyon sign.
  • When the ET causes local skin infection – called bullous impetigo and when it disseminates hematogenously – called Staphylococcus Scalded skin syndrome (SSSS)/RitterDisease/pemphigus neonatorum.
  • Histopathology- Blister below stratum corneum (within or below the granular layer) with plenty of neutrophils.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to your clinic after a motor vehicle accident where he sustained a minor chest trauma. His physical examination is normal. A CBC reveals normal hemoglobin and WBC count with a platelet count of 80,000/μL. He is asymptomatic, has no excessive bleeding, has no past medical history, takes no medications, and does not use alcohol. . His peripheral blood smear is shown in the figure. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The peripheral blood smear is not consistent with true thrombocytopenia because of the clumped enlarged platelets (see figure below). Pseudothrombocytopenia is an in vitro artifact resulting from platelet agglutination via antibodies (usually IgG, but also IgM and IgA) when the calcium content is decreased by blood collection in ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA).

questions.text: A 32-year-old G2P1 at 28 weeks gestation presents to labor and delivery with the complaint of vaginal bleeding. Her vital signs are: blood pressure 115/67 mm Hg, pulse 87 beats per minute, temperature 37.0°C, respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute. She denies any contraction and states that the baby is moving normally. On ultrasound the placenta is anteriorly located and completely covers the internal cervical os. Which of the following would most increase her risk for an obstetric hysterectomy?
questions.solution: Prior cesarean delivery and placenta previa, especially an anteriorly located placenta, increase your risk of placenta accreta, increta, and percreta. Placenta accreta, increta, or percreta are treated with hysterectomy. Advancing maternal age, multiparity, prior caesarean delivery, and smoking are associated with previa. Painless bleeding is the most common symptom, and is rarely fatal. Vaginal examination to evaluate for placenta previa is never permissible unless the woman is in the operating room prepared for immediate caesarean delivery, because even the most gentle examination can cause torrential haemorrhage. These “double setup” examinations are rarely necessary because ultrasound is usually readily available to make the diagnosis of placenta previa. Cesarean delivery is necessary in practically all cases of previa.

questions.text: A 31-year-old G2P1 woman at 40 weeks’ gestation has progressed in labor from 6 to 7 cm cervical dilation over 2 hours. Which of the following best describes the labor?
questions.solution: The protracted active phase means some progress but less than expected (1.5 cm/h) in the active phase of labor. This patient is >6 cm dilated, so she is in the active phase and not latent phase of labor. This would have been an arrest of active phase if there had been no progress at all. The cervix has changed 1 cm over 2 hours when the expected change would be 3 cm, therefore this is not normal labor.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female is referred with a long history of hypertension and episodic urinary tract infections. Dipstick analysis of the urine shows Blood +++ together with protein +++. Her Urea is 20 mmol/l (3-8) and Creatinine 280 µmol/L (60 – 100). An ultrasound of the abdomen is requested and shows left and right kidneys of 9 cm in size (10-12) without evidence of obstruction. Which one of the following is the best investigation to diagnose the cause of her renal failure?
questions.solution: This patient has impaired renal function, with hypertension and significant proteinuria and hematuria (? GN). The kidneys are smaller than expected, with no evidence of obstruction. Intravenous urography (B) is not the investigation of choice in a patient with impaired renal function. Isotope renography (A) would provide information about the relative function of each kidney and would show areas of scarring due to renal stone disease, infection, or vascular disease. It would also exclude congenital malformations of the kidneys. Although useful, it would not provide information on the cause of the hematuria and proteinuria. Renal angiography (C) is the gold standard for assessing renovascular disease. It is an invasive procedure, with potential complications. This investigation would not exclude causes of proteinuria and hematuria. Retrograde pyelography (E) would be useful if there were any evidence of obstruction. The best investigation is a renal biopsy. This would show any changes of GN, along with renal scaring from longstanding hypertension or urinary tract infections.

questions.text: A 22-year-old student presents with dark urine like ‘black tea’, followed by swelling of the eyelids associated with malaise, anorexia, and weakness. She has no relevant medical history although she reports having had an infection at the site of a skin piercing approximately 4 weeks previously, for which she has been prescribed some antibiotics. She took 2 days of these but stopped because the infection cleared and she developed some abdominal pain while taking them. Her urinalysis is as follows: Protein 3+, Blood 3+, Nitrites Negative, and Leucocytes Negative. The likely diagnosisis:
questions.solution: This young woman has presented with nephritic syndrome. The length of time after her skin infection makes the likely diagnosis a PSGN. Immunoglobulin A (IgA) nephropathy usually occurs with upper respiratory tract infections and usually either at the same time or within 2–3 days of them. Acute intermittent porphyria can cause urinary discoloration when the urine is left to stand in sunlight, but this lady has dark urine when it is passed. The clinical features, in any case, are not those of this form of porphyria which typically presentswith neuropathy, severe episodes of abdominal pain, and neuropsychiatric disturbance. Alkaptonuria is an inborn error of the metabolism of tyrosine, resulting again in urine which turns black on standing due to excretion of homogentisic acid which is oxidized on contact with air.

questions.text: In an 8 day old child with history of consanguinity in the parents, the mother reports blisters and bleeding off of the skin at the site of handling and pressure. There was a similar history in the previous child which proved to be fatal. The diagnosis is :
questions.solution:
Blisters at the site of handling and pressure congenitally suggests EB

  • Epidermolysis bullosa-Skin fragile characterized by blistering of skin and mucosa following minor mechanical trauma physical injury /pressure handling.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man with a BMI of 32 refers to you with a history of headaches. BP (BP) during regular examinations has been approximately 186/98 mmHg. He is taking no medications and is a nonsmoker. His eGFR is 49 ml/min/1.73 m2 and he has 1.7g of proteinuria per 24 hours. His fundus examination was normal. No abnormalities were identified on renal ultrasound. What would you do next?

choices.text: Control his BP and then a renal biopsy.
Use an ACE-Inhibitor to optimize his BP

questions.solution: Rule out renal pathology as a cause of his deteriorating renal function, option b is correct, all other options are false.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child suffering from recurrent attacks of polyuria since childhood presents to OPD. On examination, he has short stature, normal vitals, and normal BP. Serum creatinine 6 mg%, HCO3 is 16 mEq, Na+ is 134, K+ is 4.2 and ultrasonography shows bilateral small kidneys. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A child with polyuria, normal BP, metabolic acidosis (low HCO3), and bilateral small kidneys favors nephronophthisis

  • Nephronophthisis:
  • Autosomal recessive disorder with renal fibrosis, tubular atrophy, and cyst formation
  • It is a common cause of ESRD in children and adolescents
  • Associated external findings include
  1. Retinal degeneration (Senior-Loken syndrome)
  2. Cerebellar ataxia (Joubert syndrome)
  3. Hepatic fibrosis (Boichis disease)
  • Symptoms include polyuria, failure to thrive, anemia, hypertension, and edema.

questions.text: The patient’s repeat hemoglobin and iron studies became available, and are as follows: Hgb 9.2 g/dL Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 102 fL (elevated) Iron 30 μg/dL (normal 45–160 μg/dL) Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) 220 μg/dL (normal 228–428 μg/dL) Ferritin 90 μg/L (normal 15–300 μg/L) Transferrin saturation (TSAT) 13 % (normal 20–50 %) Based on the above laboratory values, which one of the following treatment strategies is APPROPRIATE?

choices.text: Oral iron and folate and/or vitamin B12

questions.solution: The patient has iron deficiency anemia of chronic disease; however, the MCV is high due to deficiency of folate, B12, or both deficiency. The deficiency of these vitamins and iron seems to be related to insufficient nutrition. Measurement of folate and B12 in this patient with alcohol use is indicated. On the other hand, iron deficiency in CKD patients is common due to a variety of causes, including blood loss, poor iron absorption, inflammation, and elevated levels of hepcidin. Oral iron use alone may not be adequate in this patient (option A). Oral iron therapy has not been tried in this patient. Therefore, oral iron (ferrous sulfate 325 mg three times daily) to deliver approximately 200 mg of elemental iron should be tried first with 5 mg of folate and/or 100 μg of B12 injection. Oral iron (325 mg equals 65 mg elemental iron) therapy should be continued for 1–3 months with measurement of iron indices. Thus, option D is correct. IV iron can be considered once oral therapy fails. ESA therapy is not indicated at this time (option C).

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady presented with goiter with multiple nodule and thyrotoxicosis. Scan sowed hot and cold areas. Most of the nodules were cold while internodular areas were hot. What should be the best treatment for her?
questions.solution: Diagnosis in the above case is Toxic nodular goiter (Secondary thyrotoxicosis) and is best treated by Surgery (Subtotal thyroidectomy).

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl sustained blunt abdominal trauma.She was diagnosed with splenic rupture. Her pulse is 110/min and her BP is normal. She is tachypnea with a respiratory rate of 22/min and she is anxious. Her approximate blood loss is –
questions.solution:
Symptoms Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV
Blood loss (% blood volume) 15 15-30 30-40 >40
Blood loss (mL) 750 50–1,500 1,500-2,000 >2,000
Heart rate (1/min) <100 >100 >120 >140
Blood pressure (mmHg) Normal Normal Reduced Reduced
Breathing rate (1/min) 14-20 20-30 30-40 >35
Consciousness Low restlessness Moderate restlessness High-grade restlessness, Disorientation, Disorientation lethargy

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with a lesion in the face.The biopsy was taken and the HPE slide is shown in the image.What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: The histopathology shows the characteristic “peripheral palisading” seen in basal cell carcinoma.

questions.text: An infant presents with failure to thrive, past history of seizures and presently having skin rash. Investigations show metabolic acidosis, increased blood ketone levels. This child is likely to be suffering from?
questions.solution:
Approach to acidosis with ketosis

Skin rashes with the presence of ketones and metabolic acidosis are all features ofMultiple carboxylase deficiency.

  • Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency- microcephaly, hypopigmentation, musty body odor.
