questions.text: A woman comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. Examination reveals that her uterus is considerably larger than her gestational age would predict. An ultrasound examination is ordered and reveals that she has polyhydramnios. Which of the following congenital defects of the fetus would be most likely to be associated with this abnormality?
questions.solution: Polyhydramnios is the presence of excess amniotic fluid. Because the amniotic fluid is normally swallowed by the fetus, esophageal atresia, an obstruction of the esophagus that prevents the fetus from swallowing the amniotic fluid, an excess of fluid is retained in the amniotic cavity.

questions.text: A 60-year old lady with a family history of breast cancer presents with blood-stained discharge from the nipple and a sono-mammogram is normal. The next best investigation would be –
questions.solution:
Since she is a high-risk woman givena family history of breast cancer, MRI is the next best investigation for her. MRI is important for imaging breast in the following settings:

  • To distinguish scar from recurrence in women who have had previous breast conservation therapy for cancer (although it is less accurate within 9 months of radiotherapy because of abnormal enhancement).
  • For assessing the multifocality and multicentricity in lobular carcinoma and to assess the extent of DCIS.
  • Best imaging modality in breasts of women with implants.
  • Screening tool in high-risk women (because of family history)

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male patient presenting with a hearing loss complaint was subjected to audiometry. His audiogram is shown below

What is the most possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Boiler notch/Acoustic dip is seen in Noise-induced hearing loss

NIHL

  • Boiler notch at 4000Hz
  • A notch is seen in the BC curve
  • AC curve notch are insignificant
  • Maximum seen at 3000-6000Hz
  • Sound causing maximum NIHL 2000-3000Hz
  • Stereocilia of Outer hair cells are first to be affected

questions.text: Hajari Lal, 68 Year male was operated for cataract surgery by phacoemulsification with PC-IOL implantation. After two days he developed a shallow anterior chamber with an IOP of 38 mm Hg. Gonioscopic examination shows 360 degrees of closed anterior chamber angle. Multiple peripheral iridectomies tried could not relieve the attack, diagnosis is-
questions.solution:
Raised IOP in a pt. Underwent cataract surgery with IOP implantation and angle-closure, which could not be relieved with peripheral laser iridectomies is highly suggestive of malignant glaucoma, and rulesout the pupillary block glaucoma, in which peripheral laser iridectomies relives the attack

Features of Malignant glaucoma

  • Shallow AC
  • Raised IOP
  • Angle Closer
  • Patent Peripheral iridectomy
  • Absence of suprachoroid effusion In Phacogenic glaucoma there is a reaction in the anterior chamber but depth remains normal

questions.text: 65 yrs old man with history of back pain since 3 months. ESR is raised. Marked stiffness on examination. Mild restriction of chest movements. On Xray,syndesmophytes are present. Diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• Ankylosing hyperostosisis a form ofdorsopathy
  • Ankylosing spinal hyperostosisrefers to stiffness or fusion of the spine due to excessive bone formation.
  • It is also known as diffuse idiopathis skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) or ankylosing vertebral hyperostosis,and is often incorrectly called Forestier's disease.
  • Ankylosing spinal hyperostosis affects three or more vertebrae between the chest and pelvis. Radiographs of the spine typically demonstrate thoracic spinal involvement; however, diffuseidiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) can also affect the lumbar and cervical spine.
  • DISH is distinguished by the presence offlowingsyndesmophytesalong, but separated from, the anterior aspectof the vertebral bodies,involving at least 4 levels.

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 43 year-old with vague abdominal pain Contrast-enhanced axial CT image in mid-abdomen
questions.solution:
Imaging Findings

  • CT is probably study of choice now
  • Isthmus (fused portion) is usually functioning renal parenchyma but can be fibrous
  • Isthmus is anterior to aorta and inferior vena cava and posterior to inferior mesenteric artery

questions.text: Resonance Frequencies are natural frequencies that vibrate a mass with the least amount of force. Resonance frequency for Concha is
questions.solution:
Resonance Frequencies: natural frequencies that vibrate a mass with the least amount of force

  • Concha: 4000–6000 Hz
  • EAC: 2000–3000 Hz (primary frequencies of speech)
  • TM: 800–1600 Hz
  • Ossicles: 500–2000 Hz
  • Middle Ear: 800 Hz

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is noted to be in active labor at 40 weeks gestation. Delivery of the fetal head occurs, but the fetal shoulders do not deliver with the normal traction. The fetal head is retracted toward the maternal introitus. Which of the following is a useful maneuver for this situation?

choices.text: Intentional fracture of the fetal humerus

questions.solution: The patient in this question has shoulder dystocia. The McRoberts maneuver or suprapubic pressure is generally the first maneuver used. The McRoberts maneuver involves sharply flexing the maternal thighs against the maternal abdomen to straighten the sacrum relative to the lumbar spine and rotate the symphysis pubis anteriorly toward the maternal head. Applying suprapubic pressure, or pushing on the suprapubic region, relieves the fetal shoulder from being impacted behind the symphysis pubis. The internal podalic version is an obstetric procedure in which the fetus, typically in a transverse position, is rotated inside the womb to where the feet or a foot is the presenting part during labor and delivery.

questions.text: A 69-years old male patient having coronary artery disease was found to have gallbladder stones while undergoing a routine ultrasound of the abdomen. There was no history of biliary colic or jaundice at any time. What is the best treatment advice for such a patient for his gallbladder stones?

choices.text: ERCP and removal of gallbladder stones

questions.solution: There was no clear cost-benefit and no life-years were gained from prophylactic cholecystectomy, indicating no clear-cut advantages of prophylactic cholecystectomy in asymptomatic cholelithiasis. As a result, in patients with asymptomatic gallstones, expectant management is recommended.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes increases her time spent exercising in order to reduce the number of insulin injections she must receive. The increased exercising behavior is most likely to be a result of
questions.solution: Because the behavior (exercise) is increased to avoid something negative (insulin injections), this is an example of negative reinforcement

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented with muscle weakness of a few days’ duration. On examination, she had flaccid paralysis. There was no sensory neuropathy. Her BP was 100/70 mmHg. Urinalysis was negative. Investigations: serum Na 136 mmol/L (137–144), serum K 1.9 mmol/L (3.5–4.9), serum chloride 117 mmol/L (95–107), serum bicarbonate 13 mmol/L (20–28), serum urea 4.9 mmol/L (2.5–7.0), serum creatinine 92 µmol/L (60–110), urinary pH 6.5. What is the most likely cause of the biochemical disturbance?
questions.solution:
Renal tubular acidosis- is characterized bydamage to tubules ranging from PCT to DCT.

  • InPCT damage,Bicarbonaturiais seen.
  • InDCT damage,the inability to acidify urineis seen leading to urinepH > 5.5.Type 1RTAis confirmed by a urine pH that remains > 5.5 during systemic acidosis. The acidosis may occur spontaneously or be induced by an acid load test (administration of ammonium chloride 100 mg/kg PO). Normal kidneys reduce urine pH to < 5.2 within 6 h of acidosis.
  • Type 2(proximal)RTA Type 2is impairment in bicarbonate resorption in the proximal tubules, producing aurine pH> 7 if plasma bicarbonate concentration is normal, and aurine pH< 5.5 if plasma bicarbonate concentration is already depleted as a result of ongoing losses.
  • RTA causesnormal anion gap acidosis.
  • RTA 1 has calcium loss in the urineleading torenal ricketsbutnot a nutritional deficiency of vitamin D3.
Distal H+ Secretion
Renal defect Serum (K+) Urinary NH4+ Plus Minimal Urine pH Titratable Acid Urinary Anion Gap Treatment
Gastrointestinal HCO3- loss None ↓ <5.5 ↑↑ Negative Na+ ,K+, and HCO3-, as required
Renal tubular acidosis
I. Classic distal Distal H+ secretion ↓ >5.5 ↓ Positive NaHCO3 (1-3 mEq/kg/day)
II. Proximal secretion Proximal H+ ↓ <5.5 Normal Positive NaHCO3 or KHCO3 (10-15 mEq/kg/day), thiazide
III. Hyporeninemic Hypoaldosteronism Distal Na+ reabsorption, K+ secretion , and H+ secretion ↑ <5.5 ↓ Positive Fludrocortisones (0.1-0.5mg/day ), dietary K+ restriction , furosemide ( 40-160 mg/day), NaHCO3 (1-3 mEq/kg/day )

questions.text: After a laparotomy, a woman presents with complete wound dehiscence. After treating the infection, the surgeon decides for resuturing. What is the suture material used :
questions.solution: 1’0 Reversing Cutting Needle Ethilon Practical Question

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic/ alcoholic patient, presented with a 15-degree flexion deformity of the little finger what is the most appropriate management.
questions.solution:
This is a condition of Dupuytren's contracture

  • Flexion deformity- because of abnormal fibrosis of palmar aponeurosis leading to cord or nodule formation.
  • M/C cause is Idiopathic
  • MCP>PIP>DIP involved most commonly
  • Ring finger more common than little finger involved
  • Treatment: Conservative by stretching and inj. collagenase
  • When more than 30 degrees involved at MCP and more than 15-20 degree at PIP subtotal fasciectomy is done

questions.text: A 65-year-old male, heavy smoker, with COPD is having micro laryngeal surgery under general anaesthesia. He is intubated and ventilated. During the procedure, his saturation on pulse oximeter start to dip and he develops an expiratory wheeze and it is getting difficult to ventilate. Which of the statements below is the most appropriate in the immediate management of this patient?

choices.text: Increase the ventilation pressures to improve oxygenation
Salbutamol via tracheal tube or intravenously may be beneficial
Intravenous corticosteroids should be administered immediately
The airway device may be changed to a laryngeal mask airway (LMA)

questions.solution:
• This patient has developed significant bronchospasm.
  • Bronchospasm occurs when smooth muscle in the conducting airways contracts, as a result of irritability (smokers, asthmatics, volatile anaesthetics),or light plane of anaesthesia.
  • Where bronchospasm is suspected, high-flow oxygen should be delivered and anaesthesia deepened using a non-irritant volatile (sevoflurane, halothane) or intravenous anaesthetic.
  • Use of short acting bronchodilators i.e. beta 2 agonists like salbutamol intra tracheal or intravenous are highly effective.
  • Intravenous corticosteroids act more slowly to suppress the underlying inflammatory processes and may be appropriate depending on the cause.
  • Ventilation using reduced tidal volumes may be required to protect against barotrauma In a patient with high risk of bronchospasm use of a Laryngeal Mask Airway causes less irritation of the airway and so less chances of development of bronchospasm but in this case it’s a microlaryngeal surgery and so LMA can’t be used as an airway.

questions.text: A 5-years-old kid was brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. No history of fever or blood in stools. The mother says he is irritable and drinks water if given. On examination eyes sunken and Skin pinch test- the skin retracted within two seconds but not immediately. What is the treatment of the kid?

choices.text: IV Administer the first dose of IV antibiotic and immediately refer to higher center
Give oral fluids and ask the mother to continue the same and visit again the next day
Consider severe dehydration start IV fluids, IV antibiotics and refer to a higher center
No need for any treatment. Just observe

questions.solution: Give oral fluids and ask the mother to continue the same and visit again the next day This 5 years old child has sunken eyes and skin pinch goes back slowly (Some dehydration) For Some dehydration, the recommended therapy is Plan B (as per the WHO Diarrheal control program) As per Plan B, appropriate treatment for this child would be to give oral fluids and ask the mother to continue the same at home and visit again the next day.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after getting shot in the eye by a BB gun. On initial assessment, the patient has a subconjunctival hemorrhage of the left eye with deformity of the globe. The patient's vision in that eye is 20/400 at three feet. The clinician uses a fluorescein strip and finds the patient to be Seidel positive at the limbus, extending back into the sclera at the two o'clock position. The clinician decides that the patient needs urgent surgical intervention. Given this patient's clinical presentation, what anesthetic would be preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient has an open globe injury due to trauma from being shot in the left eye with a BB gun. The patient needs to undergo surgery as soon as possible and will need to be under general anesthesia.

  • Propofol decreases intraocular pressure (IOP), which prevents possible extrusion of the intraocular contents from an increased IOP.
  • Agents that increase intraocular pressure (IOP) are generally contraindicated, due to concern for extrusion of the intraocular contents.
  • Nitrous oxide, succinylcholine, and ketamine all increase the IOP.

questions.text: A child started on AEDs for complex partial seizures developed severe mucocutaneous rash and ulcers involving mucous membrane. What could be the likely agent responsible?
questions.solution: Both lamotrigine and carbamazepine can lead to severe mucosal lesions and rash, producing toxic epidermal necrolysis/Stevens-Johnson syndrome. However, Carbamazepine is more commonly used in children for partial epilepsy and has a slightly higher risk when started in young children to produce such effects.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child while playing fell down. He has developed nasal blockage on both sides and there is swelling around the nose. What is the further treatment of this child?
questions.solution:
Septal hematoma is generally secondary to traumatic septal hematoma

  • Septal hematoma is a collection of blood between the perichondrium of the nasal septum and the septal cartilage.
  • Nose is the most prominent part of the face and hence is more prone to injuries resulting in a hematoma formation in the nasal septum.
  • It is generally bilateral
  • The dominant symptom is nasal obstruction. The treatment of choice is immediate aspiration or drainage

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing. His radiograph is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• In acute epiglottitis, the epiglottis is swollen and this finding on lateral soft tissue X-Ray is known as “thumb sign”.
  • Absence of a deep well-defined vallecula, known as vallecula sign is also seen in acute epiglottitis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has thin legs and arms but a considerable amount of fat deposited on her abdomen, chest, and shoulders. Her skin is thin and atrophic and she has several purple striae on her abdomen. An MRI shows the presence of a pituitary adenoma. The psychiatric disorder most commonly associated with this syndrome is
questions.solution: Depression Cushing’s syndrome, due to exogenous administration of corticosteroids and more rarely to adrenocarcinoma or ectopic production of ACTH, is often associated with psychiatric disturbances. Depression and mixed anxiety and depressive states are the most common psychiatric manifestations of the syndrome (from 35 to 68%, depending on the study). Mania, psychosis, delirium, and cognitive disturbances also occurs but at a much lower rate. Depressive symptoms occur early in the disorder—in 27% of cases in the prodromal period. Most patients improve after the primary disorder is treated and serum cortisol decreases.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents weight loss, shortness of breath with exertion, and cough productive of blood-tinged sputum for the past 2 months. He has a 60 pack-year smoking history. CT scan of the chest shows a 5-cm mass in the right upper lobe, with right-sided mediastinal adenopathy. PET scanning reveals uptake in 3 mediastinal nodes on the right side and 1 mediastinal lymph node on the left side. What should be your next step in management?

choices.text: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy, followed by lobectomy of the right upper lobe
Pulmonary function testing, followed by lobectomy of the right upper lobe, then adjuvant chemotherapy

questions.solution:
• This patient's presentation warrants biopsy of the mediastinal lymph nodes before taking further action to distinguish resectable from the unresectable disease.
  • If the patient had evidence only of ipsilateral mediastinal nodal involvement on biopsy, his stage would be II-IA (T2, N2, M0), which would make him a candidate for surgery after neoadjuvant chemotherapy, with or without radiation.
  • If the contralateral lymph node revealed disease, his disease would be stage IIIB (T2, N3, M0), which is considered to be an unresectable disease.
  • Treatment would then proceed with chemotherapy and radiation. Therefore, the first step should be to determine if the disease is resectable before you can proceed with appropriate treatment.

questions.text: A 66-year-old lady was admitted with a rapidly extending, widespread, painful, and blistering rash, with general malaise. H/O type 2 DM, hypothyroidism, HTN, IHD, and chronic back pain. Recently diagnosed with epilepsy. O/E, she had widespread erythema and blistering, with extensive denudation of skin covering over 50% of the BSA. A diagnosis of toxic epidermal necrolysis was made. What serological investigation is most useful in assessing her prognosis?
questions.solution:
BLISTERING DISORDERS :

Depending on body surface area :

< 10% →Steven Johnson Syndrome

10-30% →Overlap

>30% → TEN(Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis)

TEN :

Prognosis by SCORTEN

Look for 7 parameters (in the image)

SCORTEN prognosis score.

Parameter

  • Age > 40 years
  • Presence of a malignancy
  • Epidermal detachment >30%
  • Heart rate > 120/min
  • Bicarbonate <20 mmol/L
  • Urea > 10 mmol/L
  • Glycaemia > 14 mmol/L
  • 1 point awarded for each parameter.
  • SCORTEN derived by totalling scores
SCORTEN Probability of death (%)
0-1 3
2 12
3 35
4 58
≥5 90

questions.text: A patient presents to you with mucopurulent urethral discharge. He reports having unprotected sexual exposure 10 days back. A few days later, he complained of heel pain and swelling of the knee joint. He also reports that his eyes are watering and are red. His skin manifestation could be

choices.text: Whitish discoloration and fissuring of the prepuce

questions.solution: Mucopurulent urethral discharge is due to chlamydia trachomatis (STD). Heel pain (enthesitis) and swelling of the knee joint (arthritis). Eye-watering with redness is due to eye involvement in reactive arthritis. Plantar hyperkeratosis with oozing is due to keratoderma blenorrhagica. Plaques on extensor surfaces would be in psoriasis. Whitish discoloration and fissuring of the prepuce is candidal balano-posthitis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old G2P1 woman at 24 weeks gestation is noted to have fatigue of 4 weeks’ duration. Her hemoglobin level is 8.0 g/dL, leukocyte count is 2.0 cells/ uL, and platelet count is 20,000/uL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Pancytopenia, a reduction in the number of RBCs, WBCs, and platelets circulating throughout the body, suggests a bone marrow process. None of the other answer choices involve low leukocyte counts (leucopenia). Low platelets (thrombocytopenia) may also be a manifestation of severe preeclampsia, and is part of the criteria for HELLP syndrome as well. Iron deficiency anemia involves low hemoglobin levels and is common in pregnancy due to decreased iron stored before pregnancy, and increased demands for iron during pregnancy. Since this patient’s blood work showed low WBCs, a bone marrow biopsy should be done. Although acute leukemia present with leucocytosis, they may present with pancytopenia, in aleukemic variants, where leukemic blasts are confined to the marrow, pancytopenia is seen. A pregnant woman with leukemia may require chemotherapy, which poses a risk of IUGR to the developing fetus. Acute leukemia itself carries a risk for preterm labor, spontaneous abortion, and stillbirth.

questions.text: A 30-years old male patient presents with sudden onset swelling and pain over the right hemiscrotum. On examination, the scrotum is reddened and tender. Which of the following statement about the affecting condition is not true?

choices.text: A probable diagnosis is a torsion
The right testis is likely to ride high compartment
If torsion confirmed, treat with antibiotics and analgesicand perform corrective surgery immediately
If torsion confirmed, treat with antibiotics and analgesic and perform corrective surgery after 14 days

questions.solution: The case scenario describes a condition of acute painful swelling of the scrotum with signs of redness and inflammation which developed suddenly in a 30-year-old man so the probable diagnosis, in this case, is a testicular torsion of the right side. Option B is correct as the right testis has undergone torsion it tends to lie at a higher level as compared to the left testis. Please note that testicular torsion is a surgical emergency and needs to be treated immediately, golden period for testicular torsion is 4-6 hours it means that if the testicular torsion is treated within this time frame there is a chance that testis can be preserved but if surgical intervention for testicular torsion is delayed by more than 6 hours we have to subject the patient for orchidectomy as testis become non-viable.
